subdebateinfo.title: Private Health Insurance: Lifetime Health Cover

talk.start.para: —Madam President, my question is to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Can the minister explain the rationale for exempting all over 65-year-olds from penalty premiums under the lifetime health cover proposal yet imposing a penalty on women who are already in receipt of the age or widow's pension and are still less than 65 years of age?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —That is a very good question. It is always interesting to have the Labor Party questioning us on private health insurance when they were the ones who tried to destroy it. They deliberately set out to destroy the private insurance system of this country. It is interesting that premium increases averaged 7½ per cent for the 13 years that the Labor Party were in power. As you will know from the changes that we have brought in, they are now, despite the increases but with the rebate and even with the recent changes, down to about 1.6 per cent.
—So you can't answer the question?

—Senator Faulkner, I am happy to answer the question. It is just that by way of preamble I should put the answer to the question in context. It is the design of the government and the government's changes to the health insurance program not only to retain the present people in it but also to give an incentive for people to take out private health insurance. The underlying principle is that there should be freedom of choice for people.

answer.para: The generic answer to Senator Crowley's question is that if there are people who appear to be affected by the changes that are being brought in, particularly in relation to lifetime health cover, then it is up to those people to determine whether they retain their private health insurance or not. It is called freedom of choice. They may retain it, if they so desire, or not. It is entirely up to the individual to decide whether they are affected by the changes that are being brought in and to then make their own determination as to whether they take out private health insurance or not.

They have the alternative of relying on the public hospital system, which has been run down progressively by the effects of the Labor Party's policies. They did not seem to understand at the time that the more people who were taken out of private health insurance, the greater the effect it had on the public hospital system. It is entirely up to what the individual determines. It is called freedom of choice.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, we are not talking about freedom of choice; we are talking about the design of your system that has got disincentives. If you could have another shot at answering the first question—
—Any shot.

—Yes, any answer. Thank you, Senator Faulkner. If a woman of less than 65 years of age has an older husband who is exempt, she will pay an additional 35 per cent on her premiums. If her husband subsequently dies, she will pay an additional 70 per cent. How can this be an incentive to join an insurance fund?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Again it comes back to the basic premise. It is entirely up to the individuals. There are always disincentives. There are disincentives if you are young and you are healthy. That is a disincentive to take out private health insurance. Why wouldn't one self-insure? In the cases quoted by Senator Crowley, those particular people could self-insure.
—An age pensioner can self-insure?

—Senator Crowley does not realise that there are a large number of people who are pensioners who take out private health insurance because they value freedom of choice, they value the freedom to go into a private hospital if they wish and they value the choice of the doctor who is looking after them. That is unlike the Labor Party's policy, which is to have no choice but to go to a public hospital and be under the care of the hospital. That is what they propose and what was their health system. Where is their policy? (Time expired)

—Madam President, my question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. What actions has the Howard government taken to improve the living standards of all Australians? With the tax reform package now through the Senate, will the minister inform the Senate of what additional reforms are planned to further grow the economy and to create employment opportunities?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I thank Senator Ferguson for that important question. I did note this morning Mr Beazley announcing in the press that the Labor Party are going to start to develop policies. It is good news. It has taken nearly four years of just blocking, and now they are going to start to develop policies. In another year or so, perhaps there will be a policy debate in the Australian community and it will no longer be a one-sided debate, which is what it has been for the last four years.

answer.para: It is good to be part of a government which not only has the policies but is also implementing them. I am pleased that during this session we have been able to put through a federal budget in surplus again for the third year in a row. That is a remarkable achievement when you compare it with the record of Labor—deficit after deficit. It was a budget which delivered the promises we made to the Australian people at the last election. I am pleased that we have been able to weather the worst of the Asian economic crisis with strong economic growth, strong business and consumer confidence, and positive signs for improvement in the jobs market.

As all Australians know, the new tax system, passed during the course of this session, will provide for Australians an extra $12 billion in personal income tax cuts. Twelve billion dollars will be given back to Australian taxpayers from the reform passed in this session. It will, in addition, boost our export earnings—something that Senator Cook would applaud, no doubt. It will provide real benefits in particular to rural and regional Australia in terms of lower transport costs, which is critically important.

The second part-sale of Telstra will give Australians a new opportunity to buy shares in a great Australian company, and it will enable us to pay off more of Labor's debt. It will also enable us to invest in a social bonus of about $1 billion. That will deliver better communication services to rural and regional Australia and it will enable us to build on the environmental program of the Natural Heritage Trust, with an extra $250 million to invest in Australia's natural resource base—something which all Australians would no doubt applaud.

It certainly has been a record of reform and achievement. Madam President, you know of the reforms in the financial sector that have gone through in this session, the better targeting of welfare assistance and the stepping up of the fight against drugs in our community— the Howard government has it across the board. But that is not the end. The programs are there for further reforms. The next big challenge is business tax reform, and we will be marching on with that reform. We will bring it into this chamber and we will put Labor to the test again. We will go ahead with the Regional Forest Agreement legislation. We will see what Labor does. Is Labor going to vote to wreck the RFA legislation as it has promised? Is Labor going to vote against resource security as it has promised?

talk.start.para: —Why don't you bring it in and find out?
—Senator Murphy, stop shouting.

—Is Senator Murphy going to go back to Tasmania and explain how he wrecked the RFA legislation? It will be interesting. We will vote for more jobs. The unfair dismissal legislation will come back to the chamber, and we will see how Labor votes on the issue of jobs in that debate. We will bring back legislation to retain youth wages. This is a government that has achieved a great deal, but there are still many challenges ahead and we will continue with the program. We will continue to put Labor to the test and, hopefully, in 12 months time—for the first time in a long time—we will start to get a policy debate. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Aged Care. Can the minister explain why the government has wasted a quarter of a million dollars of taxpayers' money on a Productivity Commission inquiry into its policy of coalescence in aged care, only to ignore the inquiry's report? Are Aged Care Australia, the Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association and the Productivity Commission all wrong when they claim that the government policy will result in a reduction in the quality of care delivered to over 20,000 nursing home residents in Victoria and Tasmania? Minister, why won't the government do something to fix the problem?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The simple answer to the question is that it is because of the terrible problems that we inherited from the Labor Party. Rather than having a knee-jerk reaction, we are considering the Productivity Commission's report. So it is not that it has been ignored. The facts are on the board: in 1995-96 the Labor government spent $2½ billion on residential aged care across Australia. The outlay budgeted for 1999-2000 is $3½ billion. That is an increase of 42 per cent since the coalition was elected to government in 1996.

answer.para: Under the current arrangements, all states and territories will receive more funding than they did under Labor's old system, both now and in the future. So this allegation that somehow there are cuts is, frankly, untrue. I will repeat that because Senator Evans does not seem to be able to take this in: under the current arrangements, all states and territories will receive more funding than they did under Labor's old system, both new and into the future. The Productivity Commission also found no evidence whatsoever of a funding crisis in the residential aged care industry. So once again we get this beat-up of the straw man that is this crisis that is not occurring.

With regard to the Productivity Commission report, the government is in the process of consulting with consumer and industry representatives prior to a whole of government decision on the recommendations and the way ahead. The fundamental thing is that, in the meantime, all states—Victoria and Tasmania included—will receive an increase in funding on 1 July.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I do not think the minister seems to understand the issue. This problem is a result of his aged care reform package and a Productivity Commission inquiry commissioned by the Treasurer, which found that the government's proposal was basically flawed. Minister, I want to know why you are not doing anything to prevent the reduction in funding to Victorian and Tasmanian nursing home providers from tomorrow when the Productivity Commission told you you ought to intervene and put a halt to your coalescence proposal. Why won't you do something to act on the basis of the report that you said was necessary? Why won't you do something to protect Victorian and Tasmanian residents in aged care homes, as the Productivity Commission has urged you to do?
—Senator Evans, your question should be directed to the chair, not across the chamber to the minister.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Either Senator Evans is deaf or he does not want to hear, or he does not understand the previous answer. I will read again the last sentence in the brief that I read before: in the meantime, all states will receive an increase in funding on 1 July. Contrast that with funding when the Labor Party was in power. They ran down residential care and withdrew $1½ billion, and they left us with 10,000 residential places short of their own benchmark. So for Senator Evans to come in and imply that nothing is being done and that we are not listening to the Productivity Commission, is totally false.

—Madam President, my question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Minchin. Given the importance of the mining industry to the Australian economy, how will the new tax package help this industry increase production and create more jobs?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: —As Senator Crane, a proud Western Australian, would know, the mining sector is absolutely vital to our economic wellbeing. In 1997-98 the minerals sector added $8.6 billion to our total national wealth. Australia has more of its wealth in mineral, oil and gas assets than all bar one of the world's wealthiest countries. It generates 20 per cent of all investment and over a third of our merchandise exports. It is our biggest export earner.

answer.para: It is imperative that we ensure the mining sector can operate profitably and successfully. That means reducing impediments to its competitiveness, particularly when commodity prices are at an all-time low. That is why we had to fix Labor's Native Title Act: to give miners more secure land access. And that is why we campaigned so hard for significant tax reform—because the current tax system is a real impediment to the competitiveness of the mining sector. It saddles our mineral exports with the embedded cost of the wholesale sales tax, which we are completely abolishing. On top of that, the slashing of diesel fuel costs for on-road use in regional Australia and for rail transport will deliver big cost savings to this industry. We are also extending the FBT exemption for remote area housing for mining. All up, the tax package will save this vital mining sector about $3,000 million every year.

There have been independent studies which suggest that the increase in profitability for the mining sector as a result of our reforms will be 7.6 per cent, and two other studies have found that the output in the mining sector will increase by seven to eight per cent, or around $1½ billion, as a result of our tax reforms. Chris Murphy, the economic modeller, has assessed that employment in this industry will increase by 7,000 people as a result of our reforms. So our tax package means more jobs, more output and more profitability for our biggest export earner. This completely contrasts, of course, with what the Labor Party is offering the mining sector. The Labor Party completely opposed all these tax reforms, which means there are 7,000 jobs which Labor is opposed to.

With respect to native title, the federal opposition completely opposed every effort we made to find a sensible balance between the land access needs of miners and the rights of indigenous people. Around the states, the Labor Party, particularly in Western Australia, is undermining every effort we have made to bring some sense to native title processes.

Labor also completely opposed our industrial relations reforms, which have been critical to ensuring that the minerals industry can maintain its international competitiveness. Labor's three-mines uranium policy was widely regarded as a complete joke, but a very expensive joke. Access Economics have estimated that it cost Australia $5 billion in lost export income between 1985 and 1995.

Labor has opposed virtually every single policy reform that helps our minerals industry create jobs and wealth for Australia. Labor has shown, by its actions, that it simply does not care about this vital industry or the men and women of Australia who work in it. We do care, and our tax reforms are tremendous news for this vital industry.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Is the minister aware of the polling research conducted by TQA Associates for the Private Hospitals Association which found that large gap payments have destroyed the credibility of private health insurance funds? Is he aware that the report concluded that `people don't want private health insurance at any price' and that `there was widespread consumer satisfaction with the public hospital system'? Will the government now end its fixation with subsidising private health insurance and make sure the industry gets its act together to eliminate gap payments?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Senator Forshaw may be surprised to hear that the government does support the public hospital system. There is no criticism of the public hospital system, the great work that they are doing, or the people who work within the public hospital system. Equally, the government supports the private hospital system and the people who work within that system. The answer to the continuing problems in health care in this country is to have a viable sector on both sides. We are purposely trying to help people take out private health insurance—as opposed to the Labor Party, which purposely tried to run down and destroy the private health insurance system. The basic premise of Senator Forshaw's question, that there is criticism of the public hospital system—
—What are you talking about?
—Madam President, Senator Forshaw asked about government policy in relation to the TQA assessment. If Senator Forshaw had read that report, he would know what I am talking about.
—Have you read the report?
—Order! Senators on my left should cease interjecting. Senator Herron has the call to deal with this question.

—The reality is that the 30 per cent rebate on private health insurance has made health insurance more affordable, and we have seen that demonstrated. The rebate reduces the cost of private health insurance premiums by 30 per cent, regardless of a person's income, the type of membership—hospital, ancillary or combined—or the level of cover. Addressing gap fees is one of the most difficult problems that the government is addressing. I agree with some of Senator Forshaw's questions, because it is reality. Even the Labor Party understands that, and I welcome Senator Forshaw's keen interest in retaining private health insurance in this country. At the present, one of the problems is that medical providers have largely refused to enter into price agreements with funds or hospitals because of the perception that this represents the first step in a shift towards American-style managed care. Recent negotiations have been promising, but they have been held up by the current dispute within the AMA. Eventually, I am sure, that will be resolved.

answer.para: Senator Forshaw interjecting—

talk.start.para: —There are other initiatives to address these gaps—and Senator Forshaw, if he was listening rather than calling out across the chamber, would hear what they are. They include ongoing promotion of simplified billing and informed financial consent—including work with the Health Insurance Commission to enable a broader application of electronic commerce—and recent changes to legislation which will allow health funds to cover gaps for pharmaceutical benefits and schedule medicines dispensed in hospitals.

answer.para: The government has also committed funds to supporting a number of coordinated care trials in the private health sector so that privately insured people can also benefit from programs which can help people stay out of hospital and continue to live independently at home. Early discharge trials are in place to test alternative models of providing in-hospital care that will be more appropriate and cost effective. Trial evaluations are expected to be completed early in the year 2000.

The rebate was introduced to arrest the decline in private health insurance participation rates. The official figures for the March 1999 quarter, released on 20 May, show an increase in coverage of 0.2 per cent from the previous quarter. That is the first increase in coverage for more than a decade. At the end of the March quarter, 30.3 per cent of the population were covered by private health insurance, and that is the first upturn we have seen in many years.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. I refer to the Jabiluka uranium mine, and I ask the minister: is there anything which would convince the government that the Jabiluka uranium mine should be stopped? If so, what should that be? For instance, would the impact on cultural values be enough to stop this mine?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The trick must be in the tail, which I have not heard yet. As the honourable senator knows, this application went through almost three years of rigorous assessment to the highest of standards. The findings were that the mine could be conducted in both an environmentally and culturally safe way. On that basis approvals were given, and the decline has already been constructed. It will enable the resource to be mined and processed as a flow-on from the huge Ranger mine, which has been up there for about 18 years—a mine that the Australian Labor Party did not find offensive in any way. Certainly they did not suggest in their 13 years of government that the Ranger mine would put the national park in any jeopardy. As I said, we do have the comfort of the fact that Ranger also has been mined in an environmentally and culturally safe way for some 18 years, which gives us considerable confidence as to the validity of the previous assessments on Jabiluka.
—Different mine, different place. This is totally irrelevant.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, you are out of order.

—The answer to the question, therefore, is that approvals have been given, the decline has been constructed and the ore body in due course will be mined. The benefits that flow from that are considerable wealth, direct financial benefits to the indigenous communities in the region and jobs for more Australians. Senator Cook would applaud a contribution to our balance of payments problems and a contribution to meeting the demand for uranium from those countries that use uranium as their principal fuel source for power, in particular France. The benefits that are flowing from this development are significant. As I said, it is environmentally and culturally safe and this government has given the required approvals.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. I ask: isn't it the case that this mine will rip apart a culture, break the connection between the Mirra people and the places that are part of their spirituality, and have a significant effect on the world heritage values of Kakadu? Again I ask the minister: will you please stop the Jabiluka uranium mine?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The honourable senator knows that the Mirra people agreed in writing to this mine in the 1980s. The honourable senator will also know that in the early 1990s they came down to Canberra and lobbied the Labor government for this mine to go ahead.
—What a deceiver you are.

—That is not deceiving anyone; that is a matter of fact. You cannot have it both ways. You cannot enter into a contract for the development of the mine, as the Mirra people did, and then say that you have changed your mind and you no longer wish it to go ahead. It is the same obligation that is on all Australians. The distinction which Senator Allison should be aware of is that in this instance the indigenous people have to agree to the mine. The point is, they have agreed to the mine—and in that way they have an added benefit that the rest of Australia does not have. But the problem is, they did agree to it.

subdebateinfo.title: Aged Care: Health and Community Care Fees

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Aged Care. Is the minister aware that, as of tomorrow, people in WA, 90 per cent of whom will be pensioners, will be required to pay fees for home and community care services that could total $80 to $100 a month? Can the minister confirm that nationally the government expects user-pays fees for HACC services to raise 20 per cent of the cost of these services? Is the minister aware that, on the basis of HACC funding in the budget, the 20 per cent target represents $175 million per year? How can the minister justify raking back $175 million from some of the most financially disadvantaged in society for services they cannot live without?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I have always been careful of accepting statements made by the opposition in relation to HACC, in particular in relation to aged care. While not accepting the statements made, the government is honouring its 1996 commitment to maintain a strong rate of growth in the HACC program. The increase of five per cent, or $24 million, in Commonwealth funding for the year is consistent with this aim. The level of funding reflects the government's 1996 decision on HACC funding, which recognised the importance of consumers taking greater responsibility for the cost of their care and services.

answer.para: Through the implementation of this initiative, states and territories have the opportunity to adjust their fees so that user charges are applied consistently and fairly in all jurisdictions and to ensure additional funds are available to expand services for those with the greatest need. The fees approach ensures that people who are unable to pay are not denied services, and it protects people on low incomes who require a large number of services.

Victoria has already successfully implemented a HACC fees policy which increased available HACC funds in that state by around 20 per cent over and above what is provided by the Commonwealth and state governments. As I said, the government promised to maintain the six per cent real growth in the HACC program, and it is consistent with that that the Commonwealth initiatives have been implemented.

The impact of this initiative on different states and territories has been mixed. The level of user charges collected prior to 1995-96 in the HACC program varied greatly between the states. In 1992-93 it was estimated that nationally an amount equivalent to 10 per cent of Commonwealth and state HACC program expenditure was collected in fees with different states' levels as follows: Victoria, 18 per cent; Queensland, 17 per cent; ACT, 10 per cent; New South Wales, eight per cent; Western Australia, six per cent; Northern Territory, six per cent; South Australia, five per cent; and Tasmania, two per cent. I think that will explain the background to Senator McKiernan's question.

Tasmania is implementing a policy to actively increase the rate of fees collection, although acquittal information concerning the level of the increases is not yet available. The rate of fees collection in Victoria is estimated at between 18 and 20 per cent. The New South Wales Minister for Ageing and Minister for Disability Services has sought assurances that the budget initiative, which has reduced the rate of growth of government funding, not apply in 1999-2000 when the target of 20 per cent collection would otherwise be assumed to be achieved. It does vary from state to state. It is a Commonwealth-state responsibility and, where the effect varies between states, it is consistent with the state intervention.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for the useful background information, and in doing so I note he did not answer the specifics of the question. I was referring to my constituents in Western Australia and my first question was: is the minister aware that, as of tomorrow, people in WA—90 per cent of whom will be pensioners—will be required to pay fees for home and community care services that could total $80 to $100 per month? That is significant for my constituents, Minister. Further, won't the new HACC fees faced by pensioners in Western Australia from tomorrow absorb all of the compensation offered under the tax package?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —It is not true, in relation to the tax package, that those fees will be absorbed by the increases that Senator McKiernan talks about. Under the new tax system, in relation to pensioners for example, the program will result in pensioners being more than compensated. For example, all nursing home and hostel residents will be fully and permanently protected from fee increases following the government's four per cent compensation package in July 2000. People on the HACC program will also be more than compensated because a lot of those charges will be GST free. You cannot qualify a percentage increase when it is a joint Commonwealth-state agreement and where the states have primary responsibility for those fees.

—Madam President, my final question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, Senator Hill. In each of the last two years what volumes of whole logs have been exported from Western Australia? Does the minister expect the export of whole logs to increase now that controls of the export of unprocessed wood from WA has been lifted?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable senator for her question. We all know her interest in forests and we wish her well in her retirement and hope that she might pursue the good management of Western Australian forests in her spare time. It also gives me an opportunity to recognise again the importance of the Regional Forest Agreement in Western Australia, which no doubt the honourable senator will applaud. It is an agreement which provides for a world-class reserve system. It is comprehensive, adequate and representative and provides resource security in both an ecologically sustainable way and an economically sustainable way. It is a win-win outcome, good for the economy and jobs within the forest industry and good for the environment as well.

answer.para: Specifically in answer to the question that Senator Margetts asked, I am advised that in each of the last two years no licences were issued for the export of hardwood whole logs from Western Australia, other than for a small amount of sandalwood. One licence was issued during this period for the export of soft wood, but I am not aware of what volumes may have been exported under this licence. I would expect that exports of hardwood whole logs will be determined in future by the market demand for such a resource. However, as the honourable senator knows, this government is an enthusiastic supporter of value adding and, in relation to the Western Australian timber industry, through the RFA, the $20 million contribution from the Commonwealth will be for the RFA industry development package which will assist and promote increased value adding in the industry—something that I would also think the honourable senator will applaud.

Lastly, I would invite her—she will not be here but she will no doubt have some spiritual influence on the ALP—to urge the ALP to support the government's RFA legislation. The RFA gives 20 years of resource security, which is good for the industry. But the Labor Party is determined to wreck the additional level of security the government offers through Commonwealth based legislation. The Labor Party is determined to have passed an amendment which will destroy the sovereign capacity of the federal government to negotiate resource security agreements with the states.
Senator O'Brien interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator O'Brien is a leader in wanting to destroy resource security in the forest industry, and Senator Murphy ought to stand up to him and say, `Tasmania wants resource security in the forest industry.' It is time they had a policy.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There is far too much noise in the chamber on both sides. Senators will come to order.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order on the question of relevance. In his fury, should Senator Hill be drawn to the fact that the WA government is actually falling apart with regard to the RFA legislation?
—There is no point of order.

—The WA RFA will give 20 years of security to the industry. If the Labor Party in this place would support our RFA legislation, there would be another level of security. Senator Murphy ought to stand up for resource security in the industry.
—Why don't you bring it on for debate?
—Senator Murphy, stop shouting.
—He ought to take Senator O'Brien aside and give him a talk about how important it is.
—Bring it on. It's your decision.
—The ALP is determined to destroy this industry, and that is an embarrassment.

answer.para: Senator Murphy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Murphy, are you aware of the provisions of standing order 203? I suggest you read it.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I had no idea what passions that question would release. Senator Hill indicated that there have been no exports of hardwood in the last couple of years, but without any export controls that does not indicate what will happen in the future. What does that mean for the government's commitment to value adding and employment in the industry when we all know that exporting hardwood whole logs, or whole logs of any sort, is job destroying? I indicate to the minister that, if I do find myself under the pyramid contemplating my navel with the crystals in my hand, I will be using my spiritual influence to influence the ALP in the other direction, not to support the RFA legislation.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —That is disappointing, I have to say, because the Labor Party need their backbone stiffened on this one. They are divided. They do not know which way to go. They have Senator O'Brien pulling away from job security. They have Senator Murphy pulling in a different direction. All they need to say to us, perhaps through their leader, is, `We will support the government's RFA legislation.' I am sorry to embarrass Senator Faulkner in this way. He knows a lot about the forest industry. We all remember the mess he got into when he was environment minister. Support the government's RFA legislation is all the ALP need to do. Exporting logs is not job destroying—it can actually create jobs—but value added is better still. This government therefore is investing in value adding in the forest industry and will continue to invest for that objective.

—My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. I ask the minister whether he can explain why, in answer to questions about the follow-up stage of the stolen generations inquiry at the recent estimates and in response to a suggestion that he had snubbed Sir Ronald Wilson by refusing to meet with him, he said, `I certainly met with Sir Ronald Wilson'? Further, in response to the same questions in the Senate on 26 May this year, he said, `I certainly met with Sir Ronald Wilson. We certainly discussed the implementation of the report or where it should go.' Yet, in an answer to a question taken on notice at those estimates hearings the minister has stated in writing that he has `not met with Sir Ronald or other members of HREOC in relation to the follow-up project'.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —There is a very simple answer to that question posed by Senator Bolkus. If Senator Bolkus had read the whole of the transcript of the estimates report, he would have seen that I said at the time, `I will check the dates.' I said, `I certainly met with Sir Ronald Wilson.' I said that I did met with him; I discussed the report; I was not certain of the dates; I said I would get back to Senator Bolkus about the dates of the meetings.
—What?
—As a result, Senator Faulkner, of the estimates report. I was not sure of the dates on which I met Sir Ronald Wilson.
—You've had plenty of time to get back.
—Well, we have got back, Senator Carr; and that is why Senator Bolkus is asking the question today.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the restated assurance by the minister, I ask him again: why has he recently provided the estimates committee with the answer in writing that he has not met with Sir Ronald Wilson or other members of HREOC in relation to the follow-up report? Minister, isn't it a fact that there is only one explanation for your inconsistent answers, and that is that you have deliberately misled the Senate on two occasions in order to conceal your failure to meet your responsibilities on this, one of the most fundamental issues, the burden of which is still being met by most indigenous families in this country?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —As I have explained, I said that I did meet with Sir Ronald Wilson—no question that I did. I met with Sir Ronald Wilson when he came to see me about the report.
—You said you didn't.

—Senator Bolkus then asked in the estimates when that occurred. I said that I did not recall what the dates were, that I would get back to him with the dates. The question that was then asked was: `Did I discuss the implementation of his report?' I said that I would reply in writing because I could not recall the dates; that I could not recall what occurred at the time. It is a very important question that Senator Bolkus has asked and, at the end of question time, I will supply a supplementary answer.
—Oh! And an apology.
—If Senator Bolkus is kind enough to ask me another question because we have run out of time, I would be happy to do that.

—My question is directed to Senator Alston, the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Will the minister inform the Senate how the government's new tax plan will further assist small business? What progress is the government making in its efforts to improve Australia's economic fundamentals and to improve living standards for all Australians? Is the minister aware of any alternative policy proposals, and is the government giving these any serious consideration?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Our new tax system will be a huge boost for small business. It will mean that they will be able to get a GST credit for all their purchases—something like a $10 billion windfall for business on business to business transactions. A single comprehensive pay-as-you-go taxation system with one single return required to be submitted rather than all of those other complicated requirements will be a huge advance. It is hard to imagine why anyone in their right mind could oppose the policy approach. But of course they have.

answer.para: So what is the alternative on offer? Of course, Mr Beazley is now saying that those interested in the position of party president have to come up with formulating policy, that that is their job. I would have thought that that was the job of the Leader of the Opposition. After all, Barry Jones has been there for about five years, making policy suggestions until they come out his ears, but no-one takes any notice of him; although I noticed the other day he said on the last campaign near Sydney he flew to his destination in a Saab, was picked up in a Volvo, drank from an Orrefors glass and used some flash Swedish camera. Maybe that is his idea of a good time in the workers' party. To his credit he has at least tried to deal with policy issues. Unfortunately, of course, nobody goes to Mr Beazley any more. In a recent Australian we find that suddenly Mr Simon Crean is regarded as being a bit more approachable: `Mr Beazley is in the bunker; he can't be found.'

If we look at where we are in terms of alternative policy approaches, what we have is this. The Labor Party talked about policy before the last election—they had three years to talk about it. Then during the campaign Mr Beazley said, `When I actually get into power, I'll put forward a set of policies.' That was six or eight months ago. What he said after the election was, `We've got to do a ground up review'—that was months ago. That is what we are going through at the moment. Then he set up six policy review committees, not to develop good and effective policy but to develop vote winning policies—the ALP is only interested in its own self-interest.

Now he has launched an intensive program of policy development and what are we going to begin with? A series of seminars. So the book clubs are being replaced by debating societies. What we are going to find is that we will have policy quality circles where they will all come together, and it will be sponsored by the ACTU—and of course they will pay very handsomely for the privilege of attending. There will be three days hand-wringing to start with, so that people can express their concerns about inequality and the desire for security in relation to unemployment. Hands up all those who are against a desire for security? It should not take long, but I am sure it will because they will need to string this sort of nonsense out for another 12 months or so. They probably have the trade union working group working on the terms of reference for these seminars right now.

We could set up a royal commission. If they really want an effective way of ensuring that people are forced to give them quality policy ideas, maybe we could compel witnesses to attend. It is very hard to see how this sort of mickey mouse nonsense—substitutes for policy—is going to make any difference at all. Mr Beazley was telling his MPs in caucus yesterday that they have to get out and sell the policy. I thought that was the job for the Leader of the Opposition. The trouble is, of course, you cannot sell them. You really cannot even give them away. They tried at the last election, and what did Mr Beazley say? He said, `We had a whole range of policies. The trouble was no-one wanted to talk about anything else but tax.' That is the very sort of thing that Mr Della Bosca said they did not want to talk about. They should have been told about the alternative. But of course, as soon as you put your hand up and talked about Toorak tractors and capital gains tax, of course they ran a million miles. It is really a hopeless situation. The only alternative is to get fair dinkum about policies. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Aged Care. Can the minister confirm that the budget provided for no increase in the funding for aged care advocacy services? Is the minister aware that these services currently hold a total budget of $1.719 million which represents about 0.4 per cent of the aged care budget? Given the increasing numbers of people receiving aged care, how can the government justify freezing the budgets of organisations which represent their interests? Can the minister explain how the interests of aged care recipients are to be protected when the budget allocated less than $5 a year to provide them with advocacy services?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Denman for her question. Advocacy services are funded to provided information and support for residents and potential residents of residential aged care facilities. Advocacy services are funded on an annual basis. The level of funding is based on submissions by services and is linked to the size of the client population in the region to be covered. Annual funding using grant agreements allows the department to elect not to renew funding for any organisation for the following year, and this decision is at the department's discretion. In considering the distribution of funds for the Residential Aged Care Advocacy Program for the forthcoming 1999-2000 financial year, the department looked at the distribution of funds nationally and the relative proportions of program funding which have been attributed to client services and administrative costs. Consideration of the submissions by the department highlighted the inequities in the distribution of advocacy funds nationally with the Northern Territory, for example, receiving a disproportionately high level of funds compared with any other area on a population basis. So a restructure of funding was proposed by the department. It is proposed, for example, in the Northern Territory that a new service will be established which will combine aged care advocacy with the disability advocacy service. It varies from state to state and between the territories. A new program has been initiated. In relation to the other part of Senator Denman's question, if there is any further information that I can provide from the minister, I shall do so.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Yes, I would like further information, if the minister has it. How can you justify a surplus of $5 billion when you do not even provide for indexation of the funding of aged care advocacy services?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —There are always competing demands. I think the justification is that there are limited funds. We inherited a $10½ billion deficit when we came into government. We brought the budget back into surplus. We have an increasing ageing population. The demand is increasing and there has to be a decision made about the proportion of funding that goes to respective services. The department has made the decision that that should be varied from state to state. As I mentioned previously to Senator Denman, if there is any further information which the minister can provide, I will be happy to approach her with that information.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator Alston. I ask the minister: is he aware that, in answering my question about the dairy industry on Monday, he made a serious mistake which I now give him the opportunity to correct? Does the minister remember he said that `essentially competition and deregulation are aimed at benefiting consumers'? Would the minister now admit that price rises following partial deregulation of the dairy industry this year did not benefit consumers at all?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am not sure precisely what elements Senator Woodley is pointing to when he says there have been some price rises. Obviously rebalancing can occur within an industry and the end result can be of considerable net benefit to consumers. Competition will always allow market prices to emerge in ways which, almost in every instance, will deliver very good quality consumer outcomes. To the extent that they do not, you have trade practices commissions and other interventionist forums. But that is the starting point to seeing whether consumers will benefit. I think you will find in every instance that that is the case. If Senator Woodley wants to be more precise about some element, then I am sure we can address that specifically. The question was asked in general terms the other day and I gave him a general answer.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I will be more specific: is the minister aware that the preferred option to compensate dairy farmers following deregulation is a transition package to be funded by a levy on milk sales? How will a levy on milk sales, which will further increase prices, benefit customers?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I have no idea whether the price of milk is likely to come down for other reasons. It may well be that, as a result of a general opening up of the market, there is more competition between suppliers and retailers and as a result the price of milk could fall sufficiently to accommodate any additional levy, but still be well below the starting price. Again, I will get the detail of that considered by the minister and see if we can add anything further.

—My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Is the minister aware that tax laws require a couple living together to have similar health insurance if they are to avoid the Medicare surcharge? Why is there discrimination against couples where only one person has an interest in having private health insurance? Will this situation be replicated under the new Lifetime Health Cover system or will a person in a relationship be allowed to have insurance in their own right without bearing a penalty because their partner has chosen not to have health insurance in the past? Does the govern ment really want a situation where one of the first questions on a date becomes, `What is your effective age for private health insurance purposes?'

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The appalling hypocrisy of the Labor Party concerning private health insurance is really staggering. We are now down to the minutiae of the detail. Let me recount what occurred under the Labor Party in relation to private health insurance.
—It is not relevant to the question.

—It is relevant to the question because—just to save Senator Forshaw jumping up and talking about relevance—much of the pressure on the private health insurance system of this country is related to the effects of the Labor Party when they were in power. The first thing that the Labor Party did was to gradually phase out the contribution to the reinsurance pool between 1983 and 1989, and that loaded $100 million onto the funds. Next, they did away with the bed day-subsidy in September 1986, at a cost of $135 million. Then the Medicare rebate for in-hospital services was reduced to 75 per cent, with the funds being required to cover 25 per cent. Finally, the Medicare agreements of 1993 effectively gave the states incentives to increase public patient throughput at the expense of private patients, thus pushing private patients into private hospitals with increased cost to the insurance funds. In fact, Access Economics has calculated that the cost shifting involved in these measures by the Labor government, including the shift from public to private hospitals, cost the funds $846 million in today's terms, which represents a 39 per cent rise in premiums. The reality is, as Senator O'Brien would also appreciate, that with an ageing population something has to be done to try to cope with the increased demand on the public hospital system.

answer.para: It is not the government that is responsible for private health insurance. Those people who are adversely affected by private health insurance premiums have the right to go to a public hospital, so they need not be affected by the system that Senator O'Brien refers to. There is incentive but no requirement or compulsion for people to take out private health insurance. It is entirely up to the private health insurance funds, whomever they might be—MBF, et cetera—to determine what the premiums are. It is a competitive market. The vast majority are non-profit making organisations. Should those funds find that there is a disincentive for people in the sort of relationship that Senator O'Brien has mentioned, it is up to the private health insurance industry to do something about it, if they believe that it is in their commercial interest to do so.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the minister that my question was about the government's proposed new Lifetime Health Cover system and the existing tax laws, which I thought were laws that this government had made and therefore that it is the government that is responsible for this situation. I ask the minister to have a look at the question that I actually asked and give the Senate an answer now as to whether there will be a change to allow the person in that relationship to have insurance in their own right without bearing a penalty because their partner has chosen not to have health insurance in the past. It is in the government's control to do that. If you cannot answer my question now, Minister, perhaps you will give me the same courtesy that you gave Senator Bolkus and undertake to come back straight after question time.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The government is working on the proposal for lifetime health insurance cover in an attempt to bolster private health insurance in this country. There is no finality—

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Clearly, the minister has no idea about answering the question or the supplementary asked by Senator O'Brien—he has not got a clue. Can I suggest that you recommend to the minister that he just take it on notice and attempt to get an answer because he does not know what the answer to this question is. He should take it on notice and put us all out of our misery.

—Madam President, on the point of order: it is a very fitting way to end this session—the moment that the minister wants to get onto policy issues, the opposition immediately get to their feet and say that somehow they do not want to hear the answer. You ought to recognise that effort for what it was: a pathetic attempt. The minister for being rolled has now become a leader of the opposition without an interest in policy and I am delighted that he took the opportunity to demonstrate it.

—On the point of order: it is apparent to me, after years of answering questions in relation to health, that not only do those opposite not understand the questions that they ask—and that is the fundamental problem for Senator Faulkner: he does not even understand his own question—but also when they get a proper and appropriate answer to the question that is asked they dispute that it is relevant. I would suggest that Senator Faulkner gets somebody on the opposition to develop a health policy so that we know what they stand for.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The Lifetime Health Cover scheme which is being developed is part of a comprehensive strategy. The first step was the introduction of the 30 per cent rebate which addressed the issue of affordability of private health insurance. Other steps will follow on from that. As I have said to Senator O'Brien previously, it is the private health insurance industry and the Health Insurance Association that are primarily responsible. We are trying to support them with a 30 per cent rebate to make up for the deficiencies that the Labor Party caused with the exodus of patients from private health insurance from 70 per cent down to 30 per cent. We are addressing the problem. What is the Labor Party doing? It has no policy in relation to health care—none whatsoever. (Time expired)
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

Senator HERRON

talk.start.para: —On 26 May, Senator Harradine asked me for details of the funding allocations in relation to the government's response to the Bringing them home report.

speech.para: Senator Patterson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —That's what we always do. I thought you would have learned, you dope.
—Senator Faulkner, you are shouting across the chamber and you are behaving in a disorderly fashion.

—On 27 May, I provided information on the various elements of the packages of measures constituting the response which involves four different agencies across three portfolios. I also undertook to seek from the agencies involved detailed progress reports. I now have this information. There is a lot of detail here which I will make available for the information of the Senate.

speech.para: In this context, I also have some additional information to an answer I gave to a question from Senator Carr yesterday about the government's response to Bringing them home. In my answer I indicated that ATSIC was coordinating the government's response to the report. I was, of course, referring to the coordination of the family tracing part of the program—the Link-up program—which is the central plan of the $64 million Commonwealth response. Senator Carr asked why Victoria was coordinating the response. Victoria is chairing a MCATSIA committee overseeing the response not just of the Commonwealth but of the states and territories as well.

The Commonwealth takes responsibility for the implementation of its own response separately from the activities of the states. This is evident from the information I will table today. In fact, the majority of the recommendations of the Bringing them home report were not directed at the Commonwealth but at the states, territories and non-government bodies such as churches. It is perfectly normal for MCATSIA activities to be chaired by different states. In fact, the chairmanship of MCATSIA is undertaken by the states and territories in turn. The next MCATSIA meeting will be in the Northern Territory and it is being coordinated by the Northern Territory government. As to the question of why there have been no meetings of officials to date, I am advised it is because they were waiting for responses from all the states and territories. I can advise Senator Carr that they were awaiting a response from his namesake in New South Wales, Mr Bob Carr. New South Wales only recently provided a response. As it is fairly detailed, I table the progress report.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —Senator Harradine asked me a question on 29 June and I have further information. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

speech.para: Leave granted.
IMMIGRATION AND MULTICULTURAL AFFAIRS PORTFOLIO
Senator Harradine (Hansard Pinks of 29 June) asked Senator Vanstone:
A.
1. precisely what action has been taken to ensure that:
- the Chinese woman subject of the forcible abortion allegations would not be forcibly sterilised;
- that all the family planning fines would be waived; and
- that she would be found a job and accommodation for her and her three year old daughter.
B. The Senator also asked:
1. How are these undertakings being monitored?
2. Can the Minister provide the Senate with an up-to-date account of how the woman is and whether these monitoring activities are going to continue until that person is safe?
C. He further asked that Senator Vanstone advise:
1. Which consular officials have seen the woman in the last 2 weeks?
2. What is the report of her condition at the present moment and the undertakings given by the Chinese authorities?
3. Is the Government going to provide a temporary visa for her to come to Australia to give evidence to the Inquiries?
The response to the Senator's questions is:
A.

1. We are satisfied with the arrangements which have been made by the Chinese government for Ms Zhu's resettlement in China. We are also satisfied on the basis of assurances by the Chinese government that she faces no threat from the Chinese authorities including forced sterilisation.
- We are also satisfied that she has no fines to pay.

- Our Consulate in Guangzhou has been in regular contact with Beihai officials involved in the woman's resettlement. They have confirmed, as recently as 29 June 1999, that she has been provided with a job and accommodation, furniture and other household equipment and that her daughter has been given a city residential permit. They have also advised that she is satisfied with the arrangements, although she has asked for a more spacious apartment, despite the fact that her apartment, at 20 sq metres is much larger than the average apartment of 13 sq metres.
B.

1. The woman has been told that she can contact the Australian Consulate in Guangzhou at any time if she so wishes. She has not done so. However as advised above, our Consulate in Guangzhou has been in regular contact with Beihai officials involved in the resettlement, as recently as 29 June 1999 and they con firmed advice of the resettlement arrangements. We expect that the regular contact between our Consulate officials and the Chinese authorities on this matter will continue for some time.

2. I note also that Ms Marion Le. Ms Zhu's appointed migration agent and founding member of ICRA (the Independent Council for Refugee Advocacy), who initially raised these allegations with Senator Harradine, advised, in discussions with senior Immigration Department officials on 29 June 1999, that to ICRA's knowledge, the Chinese authorities were honouring their undertakings concerning accommodation and employment for Ms Zhu and registration of her daughter. Ms Le has also advised that someone known to ICRA (not a PRC national) has been in touch with Ms Zhu personally and can confirm that she and her daughter are physically safe.
C.
1. Consulate officials have not been in direct contact with her because of a concern to ensure that she has the opportunity to settle into her new situation.
2. However, they have been in regular contact with the Chinese officials involved in the resettlement and the advice is that she is safe and sound.
3. The woman's application for a visa for Australia is under consideration.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —Senator O'Brien asked me a question on 28 June and I undertook to get some information for him. I seek leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard.

speech.para: Leave granted.
Would the end of cabotage require changes to allow foreign seafarers to work in Australia for extended periods of time?

Can the Minister assure the Senate that the liberalised customs and immigration arrangements necessitated by the end of cabotage would not result in an increased number of people attempting to enter Australia illegally?
The winding back of cabotage has been part of the Government `s policy since 1996 as means of improving Australia's international competitiveness.

The Government commissioned, and has now received two separate reports examining the Australian shipping industry and making recommendations on ways to make it make internationally competitive by winding back cabotage.

The Shipping Reform Group (Manser) report recognised that community standards need to be adequately protected through customs and migration regulation. It recommended greater certainty through the tightening of customs discretion in relation to decisions about whether vessels on international voyages would be considered to be imported and hence whether
crew were subject to immigration requirements.
The second report, the Shipping Reform Working Group report, was forwarded to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services in May for his consideration.
It would be inappropriate to comment further on these issues prior to the Government considering the Shipping Reform Working Group report.
