para.inline: SUBJECT: GENETIC PRIVACY AND NON-DISCRIMINATION BILL 1998

QUESTION ASKED: "I would be curious as to the Minister's response to that bill and its recommendations. Can I assume from the Minister's answer that she believes it is now time that the Government supports and introduces comprehensive legislation to protect genetic privacy—that is, to protect people's personal genetic information?"

. The Attorney-General advises me that a Government Response to the Report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee about the Genetic Privacy and Non Discrimination Bill is now being developed.
. It would serve no useful purpose to speculate about what the details of that Response might be.
. However, the Government certainly recognises that the privacy and discrimination issues raised by genetic information are extremely complex and warrant serious consideration.
. A Government Response will be tabled as soon as practicable.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.inline: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage (Senator Hill), the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources (Senator Minchin) and the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts (Senator Alston), to questions without notice asked today, relating to the goods and services tax.

speech.para: In question time today there were three dorothy dixers from the government backbench to frontbenchers, all about boosting the government's stocks—and no-one believes that—on the GST. They were ministerial puff pieces to try to beat their chest about how triumphant they are and how important this so-called tax reform is for Australia. Senator Hill told us that it would have a lot to do with economic growth and jobs. What Senator Hill neglected to tell the Senate was that the two major macro-economic model studies of the Australian economy looking at the GST found that it would have negligible growth on the GST—on the most favourable assumptions made by the modellers. On the most realistic assumptions, the modellers found that, given the dog's breakfast of a GST we now have with the comprise package with the Australian Democrats, it would have a negative impact on economic growth in Australia.

Senator Minchin deigned to tell us that there would be 7,000 new jobs in the mining industry. He is the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Encompassed in that portfolio is tourism. What he neglected to tell us was that the services sector of the Australian economy represents 75 per cent of the Australian economy and the services sector will carry a new 10 per cent levy. On the economic models that we have commissioned, there will be 100,000 job losses in Australia in the medium term because of the GST, and it will fall heaviest on the tourist industry—the industry in which young Australians often get a start from the ranks of the unemployed and get an opportunity to work. It will fall heaviest as well on our education exports where we are selling intelligent exports abroad. Every other service sector in Australia, which up until now has not been taxed, will lose employment because of the new tax impost. Those are not my words: those are the words of the independent modellers.

We had from Senator Alston the notion, fanciful in the extreme, that this was a boon for small business, but $1.9 billion in extra compliance costs borne by small business is no boon. Turning every small business company in Australia into a collector for the Australian Taxation Office is no boon and small business reject this tax out of hand. Their organisations say so, the evidence to our inquiry showed they oppose it and the complications now with the Democrat-government GST makes it even more complex. We went through the issues of a hot chook and a cold chook; we went through the issues of which food is in and which food is out. Small business are going to have to police it. They do not want it. It is no boon for small business.

We have had the Treasurer in the other place boast that prices will come down. I do not believe prices will fall anything like the level that they should because this government and the Democrats refused to allow the Labor amendment requiring that the level of tax be shown on the price label so that consumers can work out what the old price was, what the new price should be and how much tax they are paying. They do not want the consumers to know what the price really should be and work out for themselves what is happening. They want one price and one label and you work it out for yourselves. This will enable people to scalp prices and they will not fall. We will police this issue.

There might be some price falls, let me acknowledge that, but only in a few sectors and on a very few items. Let me just run through where there will be price rises. Already in the real estate supplements of every national daily paper we have the headlines, `Buy now before the GST'. Prices will go up in the housing and real estate sector. A family going on an outing to the football or the rugby will pay extra costs on admission. Taking the kids to McDonald's or Kentucky Fried Chicken or any other fast food outlet will involve extra costs on the tucker. There will be extra costs for school uniforms, shoes, books, bus fares, outings, camps, user fees and computer software.

There will be extra costs on car maintenance, car insurance, household insurance, haircuts and legal fees. There will be extra conveyancing costs and extra costs to get divorced or even to get married. There will be extra accounting costs; doing your tax return will cost more. There will be extra costs on electrical work, plumbing work, carpentry, housing in general, funerals, having your lawn mowed, having your house painted and taking your kids on a holiday. There will be extra costs on books and extra costs on public transport. There will be extra costs for Australians who go on package tours within Australia, but not for foreigners who do so. There will be extra costs on every service that is delivered in Australia. This is nightmare on main street. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —And Senator Cook is nightmare in the Senate. He just experienced that nightmare when the Australian Democrats and the government joined together to deliver the greatest tax reforms that Australia has ever witnessed. The simple question that the people of Australia are asking of Senator Cook and the Labor Party is this: if you are so opposed to this package, what is your policy? And there is deathly silence on the Labor side because Mr Beazley, when he was finance minister, knew the need for a goods and services tax, and indeed he supported Mr Keating whilst he was Treasurer in his bid for a goods and services tax. They never had the courage to take it to the Australian people. What the Labor Party regret is that we did have the courage to take it to the Australian people. What they regret even more is that we won the election, having had that courage. What they regret even further is that it has got through the parliament.

speech.para: What we have witnessed from Senator Cook today is a man fighting yesterday's battle. The new tax system is now law in this country; it has passed through both houses. It is about to get the Governor-General's signature on it. It is over and done with. It is time to move on, develop policies, produce something in contradistinction to what we are proposing. But no, bankruptcy reigns supreme on the other side in the area of policy. What Senator Cook so deceptively refused to tell the Australian people in his very short contribution was that the biggest income tax cuts to be delivered to the average working man and woman in this country will more than compensate for any increase that might be occasioned as a result of the goods and services tax. Why is it that Senator Cook somehow demands that the GST be shown on all the dockets that we get when we go shopping, when he never insisted on that for the wholesale sales tax which the Labor Party supports?

talk.start.para: —Twenty-two per cent on computers.

—Yes, and 32 per cent on jewellery, 32 per cent on cameras, 22 per cent on new cars, 12 per cent on ice-cream and 12 per cent on chocolate. All those taxes will be removed. Why is it that he wants the bed taxes in New South Wales to remain in place? Because that is part of what the Labor Party are supporting. Why is it that the Labor Party want the financial institutions duty to remain? Why is it that the Labor Party want the stamp duties to remain? Why is it that the Labor Party want the high income tax rates to remain? These are the questions that the Australian people are asking, and the Labor Party have been found wanting.

speech.para: There have been silly comments like, `The costs of leasing fees and conveyancing will go up,' which was used as an example by Senator Cook. The lawyers' proportion might, but if you have a conveyancing matter which is devoid of the financial institutions duty and devoid of the stamp duty on mortgages and the commercial sectors, then there will be a reduction. What we have witnessed this afternoon is the sad tale of a failed minister who now swans around as Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate seeking to fight a battle that has been lost by Labor.

Let Labor say whether they will reverse the goods and services tax and the new tax system if they were ever to win government. They are saying that they cannot, but we know from the honourable member for Werriwa, Mark Latham, that you can unscramble it. He has said so. If you are so against this new tax system, go to the Australian people saying you will undo it. You can undo the legislation if you want to. Give us a policy and tell us whether you are going to do that. Of course you will not, because you know it is good for the country, and if ever you were to win government you would want to see the benefits for this nation yourself. It is time that Labor got a policy of their own instead of just being negative. The Australian people deserve and expect better from the opposition.

talk.start.para: —What we have seen in the last month, and especially the last few days, is the government claiming, `We have done it. We have delivered the new tax for the new millennium.' John Howard said, `I started this off in 1974, at the time of the Asprey report, at the beginning of the debate about the GST.' You suddenly realise that 25 years ago they were advocating this tax. I was barely alive 25 years ago. This mob have just introduced a tax system that has been around for 25 years; that is 25 years just to get this one up. This tax was invented in 1945.
—By the French.

—That is right. We have adopted a 1945 French system that was designed before computers were invented. What about e-commerce, I hear you ask. How does the GST fix e-commerce? It doesn't. What about the new millennium and the changes that will happen in society? It does not deal with them. But those opposite will tell you, after 25 years of peddling the same rotten old idea, that it is a new tax for a new millennium.

speech.para: What about the Democrats? What have we seen from the Democrats? I have accused them of selling out. We have seen the Democrats cop heaps from the Greens and from the Labor Party about selling out. They rolled over on diesel. They rolled over on the tax cuts. They had said, `You can't have all the tax cuts going to the rich,' but they rolled over when the Prime Minister said no. They rolled over on Ralph. They sent a few ideas off to Ralph, and what did Ralph say this week? He waited till after they had voted for the tax package and then turned around and said, `You've got to be joking. We're not going to have a look at those idiotic proposals you sent to us.' Ralph rolled them. Then they rolled over on books. We have seen the Democrats tear themselves apart on books. We have seen them roll over on chickens. They were going to die in the ditch on cooked chickens, but they rolled over in the end. What about a bread recipe? They were rolled on that one. What about charities? They were rolled on that one as well.

The really cowardly act by the Democrats and this government was about the high rollers in casinos. When it mattered, where did they stand on that one? They voted yes on the high-roller exemptions. You will pay a GST and I will pay a GST, but if you are a high roller at the casino you will not. The casino looks after its mates. It flies you in, it gives you a thousand dollars worth of free rooms and all that sort of stuff. You get the GST exemption for that, but not if you are down there playing the pokies and not if you are down there playing a bit of two-up on Anzac Day. You are paying the GST then, but not if you are a high roller, a Kerry Packer, in the Mahogany Room at Crown. What did the Democrats do? Two of them did the right thing. Two of them voted against that amendment. Where were the other five Democrats? They took the chicken walk out the door. The only reason the high-roller casino amendment got up was that the Democrats walked out. We all thought it was a really cheap deal. We all thought that the Red Indians in America got a better deal: a few beads and a few blankets for Manhattan Island. We thought those Democrats went cheap. But it has become apparent today what the real deal was: the Deputy Prime Minister is resigning and Meg Lees is taking over. They fought hard and they got a good deal. They rolled over but, no, that is not right.

Today we have seen the Prime Minister concede that most people do not want the GST. That is a blinding flash of inspiration from the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister conceded that most people do not want it but he said he would convince them. The government are going to spend up to $90 million more trying to convince people that this is good for them. They were not content with abusing the Australian taxpayer by spending $15 million on the advertising campaign two weeks before an election. They did not mind abusing the taxpayers' pockets before the election, but now the real atrocity will take place: $90 million trying to convince Australians that the GST is good for them. The Prime Minister knows they do not want it, but he has got it through the parliament and he has bought the Democrats off. That may be at the higher price of the Deputy PM; maybe not. Who knows? We will find out this afternoon. We will see whether Meg Lees ends up Deputy Prime Minister by the end of the day. Perhaps she will.

Jeff Kennett has blown the whistle on them. He said that this is a dog's breakfast. I agree with your laughing, Senator Hill. Jeff Kennett, number one ticket holder for the GST, dragged the Prime Minister screaming and kicking into this debate. Now Jeff Kennett, who has got an election to face in a couple of months, wants to say, `This is terrible. Small businesses are going to be hurt.' That is exactly right.

talk.start.para: —Not the casino.
—It is a pretty big business, Senator Sherry; it is not a small business. (Time expired)

—What a strange, pathetic performance. What it reinforces is the fact that on the other side of this chamber we have an opposition that qualifies for one award, and that is the nitpicker award. That is all they do. They have no vision for Australia, they have no vision about a tax system and they have no vision about a business system. They have not even got the courage to speak to their Western Australian colleagues and deal with the problems that exist with native title. When the Western Australian Labor Party walked away from the proposed arrangements there, and I refer particularly to Senator Minchin's answer to my question today, they created an incredible mess for the mining and pastoral industries in Western Australia. Part of that responsibility must lie on the other side of the chamber. Those people have no idea whatsoever of the damage they are doing to the mining industry and the pastoral industry in Western Australia because of the particular position they have adopted on the native title reforms that went through this chamber. They must remember that the bottom line is that the people they are really hurting are the Aboriginal communities who lose the opportunity to become a component part of the mining industry. The opposition must always wear that fairly and squarely.

speech.para: I would be interested to hear, in the final contribution from the Labor Party in this debate, whether they actually have any vision whatsoever on where they want to see Australia in the future, in the next millennium. There have been one or two, like Mr Latham, who have said that the egg can be unscrambled, that it only requires a piece of legislation in here.

Members of the opposition talk about the tourism industry. Senator Cook claimed, quite fallaciously, that 100,000 jobs would go. He should visit tourist destinations in Australia today, especially in my home state. I was in Esperance the other day and 17 charter buses were there. The drivers all said, `The sooner we get reduced costs on fuel, the sooner we get the wholesale sales tax out of the system, the sooner it comes off parts, fuel and tyres, the better.' The cost of the wholesale sales tax on tyres alone on tourist buses is absolutely enormous. That translates to other industries, such as agriculture, mining or whatever.

You have consistently supported taxing the cost of the components that make up running a business. In doing that, your policy position has restricted the development of industry in this country. You need to recognise that. You need to catch up with where we need to be. There was a short time back in 1985, I think, when Mr Keating saw the light and tried to do something about it. I was at that particular conference. It was interesting to note at that time who led the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, back into the room with their tails between their legs. It was none other than Mr Simon Crean, who I believe was the President of the ACTU at that particular time, and if he was not, he was certainly—
Senator O'Brien interjecting—

talk.start.para: —He was President of the ACTU—thanks for confirming that, Senator O'Brien—
—I said that he showed a great deal of foresight.

—No, he did not. He held back this country for a number of years. We saw the former Prime Minister—which was not unusual for him—with tears streaming out of his eyes. We saw a shattered Treasurer. They knew that what Australia needed at that time was reform of the taxation system. They were rolled—as they have been rolled so many times—by senior officials of the union movement.

speech.para: The last thing I want to mention is the PAYE taxpayers—the workers of this country that you claim are the people who support you. Your position was to deny them tax cuts. We are not talking about the high rollers in this particular case; we are talking about the average working men and women of this country who work very hard to support their families. You were denying them tax cuts. You had a broken-down tax system. You had a PAYE tax system that was out of control. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I just want to remind the Senate, and those listening, of something. Who said that he had pushed the GST but, `I honestly think that now the GST's receded from consciousness it's been invested with some snake-oil qualities'? That was in November 1996. I will give the Senate a hint. It is the same person who, in reference to excluding food from the GST, said it would be `the nightmare on Main Street' and has since been wandering around the country waving thermometers. That same person negotiated a deal with the Democrats to exclude food from the GST. It was none other than the Treasurer, Mr Costello.

speech.para: We all remember what Mr Howard said. He said, `There's no way a GST will ever be part of our policy.' The reporter asked him, `Never ever?' Mr Howard replied:
Never ever. It's dead; it was killed by the voters at the last election.

That was in May 1995. In the last couple of days we have heard Mr Howard triumphantly proclaiming that the GST has been on the agenda for 25 years. Will he say that in his national broadcast tonight? Will he even mention the term `GST' in his broadcast tonight? According to the Treasurer, the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Democrats, we are standing on the edge of an economic nirvana—we are setting Australia up for the next 1,000 years.

Ask the French about that. Look at the state of the French economy. The French invented the GST 50 years ago. According to Mr Costello and Mr Howard, the GST is good for the states. Ask Jeff Kennett about that. According to the Liberals, the GST is good for employment. All the research shows that, at best, it is job neutral, but it may cost up to about 100,000 jobs. According to the Liberals, it will boost savings. Not one person seriously advances that argument anymore. According to the Liberals, it will be good for exporters, but according to Treasury the increase in export prices will be offset by the appreciation of the Australian dollar.

Apparently, there is going to be more money for welfare—and that is from a government which has cut billions of dollars from education and health over the last four years and which says that the GST will never ever go up. Apparently, the GST is going to be a huge boost for small business. I repeat Mr Costello's own words: `It is going to be a nightmare on Main Street.' Apparently, it is going to help families. If you are an upper income family, it certainly will help you. Apparently, it is going to boost growth. According to the modelling that has been done, average growth per capita will increase 60c a week after five years. Apparently, it is going to be good for the bush and for regional Australia. Only the National Party could agree to a whacking great new tax with some exemptions—the nightmare on Main Street. Only the National Party could be silly enough to agree to a new tax on the basic commodities produced by farmers in this country. Only the National Party could be that stupid.

A range of exaggerated claims has been made about the GST. One advanced economy in the world does not have a GST—the United States. Whilst correlation is not necessarily causation, if we look at the strength of the United States economy I do not seriously believe that the strength of the Australian economy or the strength of the US economy will in any way be significantly improved by a new tax—a goods and services tax.

I did say that only the National Party could be silly enough to agree to a tax on food—a party which purportedly represents farmers. But there is an even sillier party in this Senate—and I could be harsher in my criticism—and that is the Australian Democrats. They swallowed it hook, line and sinker.

talk.start.para: —Do you mean the opposition—the real opposition?

—I will take the interjection, Senator Calvert. Go out and sell the GST in Tasmania. I have a pretty good idea what the result will be in Tasmania at least—the Labor vote will go up. Send Senator Abetz out to sell the GST—that would be even better.

speech.para: All the promises and all the grandiose claims that have been made about a GST are, in reality, highly exaggerated and false if you look around the world at the economies that have the goods and services tax. Japan was the latest to introduce it. Look at what has happened to Japan since it introduced a GST. Look at what happened when it increased the GST in Japan. The goods and services tax will not be good for this country. It will be bad for low and middle income earners. The Australian Democrats have guaranteed that outcome—a worse outcome for low and middle income earners in this country. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Clearly it has been a terribly bad week and a bad year for the Australian Labor Party. On Senator Sherry's own admission, they will not have an alternative policy for at least a year or so. They have now convened a special policy powwow to try to fill in the interregnum. They have also, via their leader Mr Beazley, made a plea today to find a federal president who is a policy person. They are desperate to find someone who has some policy credentials and who can actually put together a few thoughts to come up with a new idea for policy.

speech.para: In the meantime, we have Mr Beazley's concept about how to handle the tax debate changing every day. Yesterday it was, `We're going to have to go down below the radar'—whatever that means. A few days before that he said, `We're going to have to walk this tax policy back,' which is dangerous for most people. I think in policy terms it is incredibly dangerous.

The question Mr Beazley and honourable senators opposite are going to need to answer for the Australian people, when they start walking back the tax reform policy, is: how are they going to walk it back? What many Australians would want to know—especially when Mr Beazley says that we are moving into the information age, we all have to get online and the future of Australia is the information economy—is: is he going to walk back the tax reform proposals? Is he going to walk back Australia's tax laws to reimpose the 22 per cent tax on computers and hardware which this Senate just last night agreed to take off?

Mr Beazley talks about taxes on books and he talks about taxes on chooks. That, in many respects, is the old economy. The new econ omy is about getting people online. It is about—to use the title of Bill Gates's new book—creating a digital nervous system. It is about rapidly increasing the quality of communications and access to information for all Australians, allowing us to communicate instantaneously with anyone around the world, and accessing enormous amounts of information, ensuring that all Australians get the benefits of that.

When Mr Beazley talks about walking back tax, the first question they need to answer when they are writing a policy is: will they put the 22 per cent tax back on telecommunications equipment and therefore put up the price of getting access to digital telecommunications for average Australians? Will they put the 22 per cent tax back on PCs, back on laptops, back on modems and back on every other piece of equipment that you need to get yourself into the digital economy or, if you are an average Australian household, that will allow your children the benefits of accessing the Internet and the enormous amount of information and entertainment that is available through the Internet? Will Mr Beazley and his acolytes opposite reimpose the 22 per cent tax on the information economy? It is an up-front tax.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics have said that the biggest inhibitor to Australians getting online is the cost of the hardware. This government has just abolished the 22 per cent tax on computers, and the opposition have said, `No, let's put it back there.' We want to know if they are sticking to that policy. Their shadow spokesman on the online economy should make an announcement about that within the next day or so because the online economy needs to know where the Labor Party stand on walking back the tax. Are you going to put 22 per cent back on computers? Are you going to put that up-front tax on average Australians getting online? That is a crucial question for the future of Australia.

The Australian Labor Party are going to have to do a lot better than that. They are going to have to say whether they are going to put 22 per cent taxes back on a range of other things. Are they going to put the 32 per cent tax back on televisions? Australia would like to move into the age of digital television. Will the Australian Labor Party, when we are on the cusp of the digital revolution, walk tax back to impose a 32 per cent sales tax on digital televisions? That is another question that those opposite will need to answer. This government has gone forward with a tax policy that imposes a GST. It took a lot of political commitment to go to an election with a policy to put a 10 per cent tax on things. (Time expired)

Senator VANSTONE

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to make a brief personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday evening the Senate debated the Criminal Code Amendment (Slavery and Sexual Servitude) Bill 1999 . I was on a pair at the time and the debate was handled by my colleague, Senator the Hon. Jocelyn Newman. During the debate a question arose about the time that had been available to the opposition to consider amendments circulated by the Greens (WA) and agreed to by the government. Senator Margetts observed during the debate that the Greens were under the impression that the agreed amendments had been provided to the opposition by the government and had been discussed between the government and the opposition. Senator Newman, in her speech in reply, confirmed that that indeed had occurred.

—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. As I was present at the debate last night, and given that Senator Vanstone's name was not mentioned at any stage as the responsible minister for the government, I do not think that it is proper or in order for Senator Vanstone to make a claim that she has been misrepresented. There has been no involvement of the said minister.
—Order! A personal explanation does not have to be in relation to something that someone is alleged to have said, but it will need to involve the minister in some way.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. At the time, Senator Faulkner chose to make what was regarded as an inflammatory and factually incorrect speech in which he made—as he occasionally does—the extremely serious allegation that Senator Newman had misled the Committee of the Whole. This accusation, of course, reflects upon me by implying that the information provided to Senator Newman on my behalf has misled her and allowed her, a colleague, to mislead the Senate.

speech.para: I wish to make an explanation that Senator Newman was absolutely correct in stating that the agreed amendments had been provided to the opposition and that, therefore, Senator Faulkner was clearly incorrect. The agreed amendments were supplied to the shadow minister for justice and customs in two parts, the initially agreed amendments relating to the extraterritorial application for the proposed offences on 12 May 1999 and the remainder relating to a new offence with an element of recklessness on 27 May 1999. In other words, the first part was supplied 48 days before the debate yesterday, and the remainder were supplied 33 days beforehand.

In conclusion, I add for Senator Faulkner's benefit that I have spoken to Duncan Kerr about this. He accepts that they were delivered. I understand the mistake that Senator Faulkner made, because he was advised by Duncan Kerr, possibly, indirectly that he had not seen them. That is a matter for Mr Kerr to sort out in his office. But we have the fax confirmations that these amendments were sent 48 and 33 days beforehand. Senator Newman was correct and did not mislead the Senate.

debateinfo.title: REPUBLIC (CONSULTATION ON AN ELECTED PRESIDENT) BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Murray) agreed to:

That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to provide for the electors to be consulted on an elected president at the same time as the Constitution Alteration (Establish of Republic) 1999 is submitted to them, and, if the electors express a preference for an elected president, to initiate an alteration of the Constitution to achieve an elected president.
Motion (by Senator Murray) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to table the explanatory memorandum and have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

This Bill has a very simple, yet very important, purpose. It seeks to give electors the opportunity, at the same time as they vote upon the Constitution Alteration (Establishment of a Republic) Bill 1999 , to send a message to this Parliament as to whether they want their Head of State elected or appointed. It seeks to counter the monopolisation of the referendum process by those in favour of the Prime Minister/Parliament appointed model, by ensuring that the preferences of the people are made unambiguously clear.

Denying the people a choice on direct election of their Head of State is fundamentally undemocratic. If our politicians deny the people such an opportunity, they will probably guarantee that their Prime Minister/Parliament appointed model is rejected.

We are all aware of the consistent and major support for a directly elected Head of State amongst the public. This Bill will guarantee that the ultimate, indisputable mass opinion poll is subsequently conducted, as is proper. Should a majority of electors express a preference for a directly elected president, this Bill provides for an elected convention to be subsequently conducted to come up with the most appropriate model for direct election. The Bill is therefore not prescriptive as to the desired model.
This process would accompany the decision to either reject or accept the proposed referendum model and would not interfere with either of those choices.

The arguments for direct election of a President have been aired in various forums. I wish to highlight the key reasons why this country's citizens deserve the right to elect their own head of state, toward which this Bill takes the first steps.

The Constitutional model that is being put forward by the Australian Republican Movement (and others) for politicians and not the people to appoint the Australian Head of State goes against the most fundamental tenet of the Australian system of government.

This system is recognised in law as being founded on the sovereignty of the citizenry. It is the people that maintain control over the structure of this system via the s128 method (requiring a referendum) of altering the Constitution.

Originally the Courts viewed our sovereignty as being derived from the Constitution being an Act of the United Kingdom Parliament. In now proposing to formally sever the tie with the United Kingdom we must understand that to withhold from citizens even the choice of determining the right to elect their own head of state would be to maintain a vestige of the old system that rested on the executive selecting a candidate for royal approval. Instead the executive will select a candidate for parliamentary approval, which will (on precedent) be dictated by the self-same executive. How can that square with the notion that it is the Australian public—not the Parliament, not the executive—that is sovereign?

A directly elected President would also enhance the separation of powers in our system of Government. The doctrine of separation of powers is insufficiently respected, but is one of the most important features of the political heritage of our nation. The politician-appointed model would denigrate this doctrine by further concentrating power in the hands of the executive. The model gives the Prime Minister summary and sole powers of dismissal, to be confirmed by the House of Representatives which would provide no safeguard. The Senate is specifically and deliberately excluded in this act of executive reinforcement.

The House of Representatives is more correctly described as the House of the Executive. The Prime Minister controls the Cabinet, the Cabinet controls the party in government, and they have the numbers to do whatever they please. The exclusion of the Senate, elected under proportional representation, ensures that the political party in power has unfettered control of the dismissal power. That is not democratic, it is authoritarian.

Contrary to the parliamentary and judicial processes of other countries, the politician-appointed model proposes that an Australian President may be removed at any time by a notice in writing issued by the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister need not provide any reason for this decision—extraordinarily, no grounds for dismissal are outlined in the model.

The President is removed immediately upon the Prime Minister's notice being issued. The Prime Minister's decision must be ratified by the House of Representatives within 30 days, but if the House does not ratify the Prime Minister's action, the President remains dismissed. This would be a pointless exercise. Meanwhile a stand-in will assume the role of President, over whom the Prime Minister also has powers of instant dismissal. Following this, it is the Prime Minister once again who selects the permanent new President.
It is clear the Prime Minister retains complete control over this process from start to finish.

Opponents of direct election have no answer to this argument. They are indisputably advocating a further concentration of power in the hands of the executive. So instead there is a scare campaign against direct election of our head of state. The scare-mongers have been careful not to attack the principle, as they know this is sound. Rather, they cite what they see as the inevitable practical outcome, that we would end up with a politician as our Head of State, as their key objection. Professor Craven ( The Australian , Friday, Feb 5 1999, p17) deliberately propagates this simplistic view :

Who could doubt for a second that both major political parties would throw all their energies into capturing that position to use against their political opponents? Who else would have the money, organisation and experience to do so? What this means is that under direct election, the president will always—by definition—be a politician.

It is by no means certain such an outcome would eventuate. Systems can be devised to ensure that candidates who are apolitical are on an even playing field with those sponsored by parties (eg. by public funding for non-aligned candidates and by requiring aligned candidates to include in their adverts `authorised by' messages such as currently occur in federal elections, so that the electors know that they are voting for an aligned candidate). Further controls on advertising may be possible now that the High Court has watered down its position on implied freedoms of political communication.

But even if it is accepted that politicians may win the presidency by direct election, why would this be such a negative? First, it would be the will of the people. If Australians vote in a politician then it is their sovereign right to do so. Second, politics gives such people a grounding in affairs of state and a grasp of the complexity of the range of issues with which governments must deal, that persons from other backgrounds may not possess.

Third, there is no guarantee that a person from outside of politics will perform any differently in the role in a time of crisis than a former politician. The Governor General at the centre of the 1975 constitutional crisis, for example, was not a politician. He was an ex-Chief Justice of the New South Wales Supreme Court. The last politician in the Governor General's position was Bill Hayden. There were no significant shortcomings in the performance of Bill Hayden, at least while he was Governor General. The truth is that there can be no guarantees of the performance of an individual by virtue of the method of selection.

Fourth, those who oppose direct election on the grounds it would deliver a politician defy reason—as they seem unconcerned that the bipartisan model would allow politicians to appoint the President. Make no mistake about this—it will be a political appointment. A committee of thirty two, sixteen politicians and sixteen prominent citizens, all possibly owing their selection to political criteria, will present three names to the Prime Minister. After selecting one, the Prime Minister will then consult another politician, the Opposition Leader, and then other federal politicians of note. No matter what result, this very process is inherently biased toward a political outcome.

I wish to make it clear that these arguments do not mean that I necessarily advocate a politician for the position, but rather they demonstrate that if this were the outcome, it would not present a problem for our political system. Australians accept a political system where the Prime Minister and his or her executive are part of the parliamentary system. We are therefore not contemplating an executive president. The President would continue to have limited powers and be largely ceremonial. Nevertheless, the limited mandate this person would have from their election would give them no less authority to speak out over issues of relevant and legitimate concern to him or her (as our present Governor General has already quite properly done in a limited and careful way), whilst continuing to perform their constitutional duties. This independence is very healthy for our democracy, and importantly provides another pivotal political institution that the executive cannot completely control.

The Government should give some thought as to the benefit they could reap out of agreeing to the initiative in this Bill. As Michael Visontay argued in a column in The Australian (Tuesday, Feb 2 1999, p13):

Surely it's not too late to ask the Government to include a second question. Howard managed to portray himself as an honest broker in the Constitutional Convention. If he adds a second question, then he won't have to worry about perceptions. And that's about as big a reward as a politician could ask for.

At the root of all this is whether our federal politicians are firstly willing to trust the people. Secondly, whether they are willing to give them the option of fully expressing their will as to their preferred means of presidential accession. The conversion of Australia to a Republic should mark an increased willingness on the part of politicians, and particularly of the major parties, to open up our political institutions to greater democracy. This Bill seeks to take the first step down that progressive road.
Debate (on motion by Senator O'Brien) adjourned.

That the Senate calls on the Government to refer the following matters to the Review of Business Taxation as a matter of urgency for inquiry and report by 30 July 1999, in line with one of the review's key objectives of `providing a secure source of revenue':

(a) the extent of the erosion of the `pay as you earn' (PAYE) tax base due to the growth in dependent contracting arrangements, including the use of company structures to receive payments for personal services, and the annual cost to revenue from such arrangements;

(b) the impact of proposals in the Government's `A New Tax System' package, particularly those contained in A New Tax System (Australian Business Number) Bill 1998 and the proposed new withholding tax arrangements, on the erosion of the PAYE tax base through the growth of dependent contracting arrangements;
(c) the equity implications for businesses and their employees subject to the PAYE tax system compared to those operating through and with dependent contracting arrangements; and
(d) measures to halt the erosion of the PAYE tax base caused by the growth of artificial dependent contracting arrangements.

talk.start.para: —In accordance with the usual practice, I seek leave to have the government responses to committee reports incorporated in Hansard .

interjection.para: Leave granted.
The responses read as follows—
COMMITTEE REPORT PRESENTED TO THE PRESIDENT WHEN THE SENATE WAS NOT SITTING

Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee—Report on the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Charges Bill 1998 and the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Amendment Bill 1998 (presented to the President on 29 June 1999 )

Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade—Report entitled Improving but . . . Australia's regional dialogue on human rights (presented to the President on 29 June 1999 )
