talk.start.para: —This evening I rise to make some comments with respect to the report of the royal commission into the Longford gas plant disaster which occurred last year. As senators are aware, on 25 September last year a major explosion and fire occurred in Gas Plant 1 at the Longford gas plant. Two employees, Mr John Lowery and Mr Peter Wilson, tragically lost their lives in that disaster. Eight other employees were injured and massive disruption occurred to the lives of Victorian citizens and to businesses.

speech.para: I rise to make these comments this evening because, firstly, as I am sure all senators are aware, I have a background as an official of the Australian Workers Union and as an employee of that union for over 18 years. During that time I was integrally involved in the oil industry and, on many occasions, I visited the Longford gas plant. Indeed, on a number of occasions I argued cases before the Industrial Relations Commission and negotiated with Esso over issues, including manning at that plant and at other plants including Long Island Point and the offshore installations.

Whilst we all hoped that the operations of those plants were safely carried out, there were occasions when the members of the union, the workers at those plants, expressed the view that manning levels were not adequate and that indeed the company's proposals to reduce manning could well give rise to safety concerns.

Like many Australians, I was therefore very distressed when I heard the news about the explosion at Longford. During the royal commission inquiry I refrained from making any public comment in this chamber or elsewhere because I believed that it was appropriate for the royal commission to be able to conduct its inquiry free from any undue, unnecessary or improper influence. I have to say that now that the royal commission report has come down it is abundantly clear that the attitude adopted by the company, Esso, was nothing short of disgraceful. Esso's tactics were to endeavour to blame everyone else except themselves. In particular, in a most disgraceful attempt, they sought to blame one of the workers, an operator, Mr Jim Ward, for the disaster that day—a disaster that, as I said, claimed the lives of two of Mr Ward's work mates and injured eight others. They also sought to attribute some blame to another employee, a Mr Rawson.

I was pleased to be able to read this week, when the royal commission report came down, that Mr Ward has been completely exonerated. The royal commission has laid the blame squarely on Esso and, to an extent, on the Victorian government and the failures of the regulatory system to ensure an adequate safe working environment at the plant. I will quote briefly from summaries of the report contained in newspapers earlier this week, firstly from the Herald Sun:
The royal commission found Esso had not learned from a similar incident a month before the September 25 blast.
It found Esso failed to train its workers adequately, put in safe operating procedures and conduct crucial safety audits.
It said cost-cutting by Esso might have contributed to the disaster because of repeated delays to safety audits of the plant.
It goes on further:
Royal commission chairman Sir Daryl Dawson said it was design limitations of the plant, not inaction by workers, that caused the fire to worsen after the initial blast.
Then there is a direct quote from the judge, Sir Daryl Dawson:

"Their attempts to isolate the plant, rescue the injured and initiate fire suppression measures were not only wholly appropriate but, in view of the personal danger they faced, also heroic," he says in the report.
He states workers at the gas plant, plagued with problems on the morning of the blast, did not know of the dangers they faced.
"Nor did those charged with the supervision of the operations have the necessary knowledge," the commission found.
This lack of knowledge was blamed directly on a deficiency in their training.

The royal commission concluded that the ultimate cause of the fire was the failure of Esso to equip its employees with appropriate knowledge to deal with events that occurred. It had failed to provide the necessary information in the form of appropriate operating procedures. It found that Esso breached the Occupational Health and Safety Act by failing to maintain a working environment safe and without risks to health. It found that the lack of knowledge of operators and supervisors was directly attributable to a deficiency in their initial or subsequent training. I just make the comment that, not only do plant operators in refineries and gas plants such as Longford have the duties of operating the plant, they also are the front-line fire crew in any emergency situation such as occurred at Longford on that fateful day.

I find it absolutely disgusting that any company, particularly a company such as Esso, should seek to avoid its responsibility by laying the blame for such a tragedy on its workers. Mr Ward has clearly been subjected to terrible stress during this inquiry. He stated:

To see two of your workmates get killed, to drag burnt bodies out of the fires and see those people now with their families struggling to recover and get over the physical trauma and the mental trauma . . .
That alone was enough to try to cope with, then I had to defend myself in the royal commission from my own employer, who I've worked with for nearly 19 years.
To have them turn around and say things about me and to me that incriminated me with respect to killing my workmates and injuring my workmates—I don't know how I can describe it.
An apology would probably be a bit hollow at this stage.

It may be a bit hollow and certainly Mr Ward is entitled to feel the way he does. In their actions following this report Esso have again demonstrated their callous attitude. They are not even offering a semblance of an apology either to Mr Ward or to the many workers at that plant. I conclude by saying that some years ago a book was written called The Other Price of Britain's Oil . It was written by a person called Kit Carson. He foretold in that book problems that would eventuate, particularly in the offshore oil industry in Britain, as a result of the failure by the then Thatcher government to properly allow and apply—in fact, the government prohibited them—the application of health and safety laws on the offshore platforms. In probably the worst tragedy in the history of the oil industry in the world in 1988 the Piper Alpha platform exploded in the North Sea and 167 workers lost their lives.

Clearly, there is a need for Esso and the Victorian government to apply themselves to improving the regulatory system in Victoria. It is not simply good enough to rely upon what is called the safety case system where companies themselves have a safety plan and they largely have the responsibility for implementing it. Governments have a responsibility to ensure that employers such as Esso do what they are required to do.

Finally, I pay a tribute to the Australian Workers Union and the other unions who have stood by these workers through that disaster. Particularly, I pass on my sympathy to the families of Mr Lowery and Mr Wilson, who perished in that tragedy. I acknowledge, as we all should, not only that they were innocent victims but that they indeed were heroes.

talk.start.para: —No government in the history of Australia has supported and fought for the timber communities of this country as has the Liberal-National coalition, nor on the other side of the equation has there been a government that has delivered environmental outcomes for this nation as has the Liberal-National Party coalition. I refer to the Natural Heritage Trust, Green Corps and the fantastic outcomes that have been achieved through regional forest agreements and the national forest policy statement processes that were commenced—to give credit where credit is due—by those on the opposite side of the chamber.

speech.para: When we came into government, we committed ourselves to the regional forest agreement process. In fact, we have been able to effect a number of outcomes for the benefit of both the timber communities, the workers and the communities that rely on the incomes from the timber industry. This government remains committed to bringing in legislation to, in effect, overarch or tie together all those existing regional forest agreements around the country and those that are still in the process of being finalised.

My home state of Tasmania, and yours, Mr Acting Deputy President Murphy—and I note the presence of the Government Whip, Senator Calvert, in the chamber—is heavily reliant on the timber industry. There are many small and large townships right around our state that are heavily dependent on the forest industry. The people of Tasmania and indeed Australia who are reliant on timber for their livelihood are very supportive of the regional forest agreement process. It is a matter of regret that within this session we were unable to deal with the regional forest agreement legislation. Certain suggestions and allegations have been made about that. Suffice it to say that the bottom line in all this is that the numbers were not in the Senate to be able to provide the guillotine and the gag on the guillotine to deliver the outcome that I and many others would have desired.

Indeed, as I understand it, neither the Labor Party, the Democrats nor the Independents were prepared to be supportive of such a move. If the government had moved in such a direction, there is no doubt that the guillotine motion that would have been moved by the government would have been filibustered out and we would still not have had the outcome which, unfortunately, was not forthcoming. It is with regret that the legislation has not been passed in this session, but the real issue for this country and for the workers in the forest industry is to put the pressure on the Australian Labor Party when the Senate resumes to support the legislation and not amend it.

talk.start.para: —Why don't we sit tomorrow?

—Senator Robert Ray says, `Why don't we sit tomorrow?' The problem is, Senator Ray—and this is one of the dangers of interjecting on a topic about which you know absolutely nothing—that the Labor Party is committed to moving a substantial amendment to our legislation.
—True.

—Senator O'Brien has indicated that that is their intention, but that substantial amendment is opposed by the Tasmanian Labor government and by the CFMEU, the trade union which allegedly looks after forest workers. So the government is in a situation where, even if it had put the legislation on the table, the result would have been such that the people of Tasmania and indeed those interested in the forest industry would not have been able to get the sort of result they wanted.

speech.para: In fact, the assertion made by the CFMEU and the state Labor government of Tasmania is that if the legislation is amended as Labor is suggesting, this will in fact gut the legislation and not deliver outcomes to those timber workers that Senator Murphy in his former life used to represent. It is astounding how sensitive certain elements of the Australian Labor Party are, when we know the divisions that exist on that side over this issue. The state Labor government in Tasmania fully supports the legislation. They sent the Deputy Premier over to the hearings of the committee, arguing and urging that the legislation be passed unamended. He does not support the sorts of amendments being suggested by Labor.

These amendments would make each RFA a disallowable instrument as a result of which the RFA process, which was to provide 20-year certainty both for conservation and industry outcomes, would in effect have been negated, given the numbers in the Senate. I urge all the people associated with the timber industry—the workers and the communities—to lobby their Labor senators to ensure that when the parliament resumes they vote for the government's legislation, which is designed to protect jobs and communities and ensure a future for an industry which has been providing support to their families on an ongoing basis for generations.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Labor Party senators can interject as much as they like, but the reality is that, during this winter break from the parliament, the timber workers will be asking all Labor senators—
—Why didn't you bring the legislation in? Why don't you go and read the statements?

—Well, Senator Murphy, would you have supported the gag and guillotine on our legislation as it stands? The answer is no, because Senator Murphy has succumbed to the champagne of Canberra and forgotten his roots—about looking after the workers that he used to represent in the forest union. You have forgotten those workers and their communities, and you now run around with the champagne charlies in the Labor Party. You have forgotten your roots, Senator Murphy, and I am sure that the people of Tasmania will be reminding you what they want out of this legislation. The CFMEU and the state Labor government supports this legislation. The big question is: why is it that the Australian Labor Party will not support the legislation being proposed by the government? They want to make amendments to the legislation which in effect will gut it.
—Tell the truth!

—Senator O'Brien says, `Tell the truth.' In that case, your Labor Deputy Premier, Paul Lennon, is not telling the truth and you might like to talk to him about why that is so. Besides being unparliamentary and disorderly, I might suggest that Senator O'Brien, the former president of the TTLC in Tasmania, thinks about the workers for a change and not about his concerns, which are to derail every proposal that the government comes up with because he never concentrates on the national good. I urge all Tasmanian timber workers to lobby Labor senators to support the legislation as printed to ensure an outcome which Tasmania and indeed the timber communities all around Australia so desperately need.

—I am almost tempted to speak on the same issue, but I actually wanted to speak on something entirely different. On Tuesday, 8 June, the report of the Forde Commission inquiry into the Abuse of children in Queensland institutions was tabled in the Queensland parliament. As the Australian Democrat responsible for this portfolio, I want to place on the public record our complete support for the inquiry's 42 recommendations, some of which I shall touch on in this speech, and also my own personal support for the Premier in making sure that this commission of inquiry took place.

speech.para: Before I do that, I want to congratulate not only the Premier but also the government for establishing this much needed inquiry nearly 12 months ago. I would also like to congratulate Commissioner Leneen Forde and her fellow commissioners and staff for the manner in which they conducted this inquiry and produced such a comprehensive report. This was an inquiry that was born of necessity and in considerable controversy. I will say a little bit more about that as well. The commission's findings are daunting, heart wrenching and overdue. In the foreword to her report, Mrs Forde said:

I have been impressed by the courage of those who came forward, often moved by the hardship they have endured, and saddened that such abuses were somehow permitted to take place. The accounts that I have heard and read have left a lasting impression, and I will never forget them.

For all those who came forward to tell their stories, and to all the victims of abuse in institutions, I dedicate this report to you, and hope that it will be a small step on the long road to healing and reparation.

Might I also add that we could have picked no-one better to conduct this inquiry than the former governor of Queensland, Leneen Forde, whose own commitment to these kinds of issues is well known; I commend her. In the conclusion to her report, Mrs Forde said:

I urge all Queenslanders to contemplate the experiences of children in institutions, how it came to pass that many of them were abused and mistreated, and why it has taken so long for their stories to be told.
It was society that failed those children. In acknowledging that, we must ensure that the same wrongs are not repeated, and that this inquiry has a positive outcome.

The Democrats endorse those sentiments wholeheartedly. The harrowing stories recounted in the Forde report should concern this chamber greatly, because the child abuse occurred against children under the guardianship of the state and the church. Where there should have been a haven, too many children found terror and abuse.

The abuse took many forms. It was unrestrained in some cases because it was perpetrated on defenceless children who had nowhere to run or hide, nowhere to seek refuge, only to endure in silence year after year. The scars inflicted on their very young minds are indelible, and for that we should all feel a very deep shame.

I was moved by some of the scenes at Parliament House, where the victims were granted permission to finally stop grieving. For some it must have been a rebirth, and their journey towards self-esteem and community acceptance had reached a new stage when the Queensland parliament, through the commission, accepted their stories and the Queensland government gave a commitment to implement the wide ranging recommendations born out of their suffering. Out of their personal tragedies and suffering in their youth—and from living with their nightmares until they could speak of them publicly—some good had finally come to them as adults.

Let me read into the record some of the recommendations of the report. They include: closing the Sir Leslie Wilson Youth Detention Centre by the end of 2000; refurbishing the John Oxley and Cleveland youth detention centres, as a matter of urgency; the conduct of regular inspection and monitoring of residential care facilities and juvenile detention centres, as specified by legislation; the provision of advocacy services for young people in institutions; the mandatory reporting of all abusive situations that come to the attention of staff; and police investigations into some cases of abuse.

Let me add that, because of my own situation and my previous parallel occupation, I feel a deep shame on behalf of the various churches of Queensland that some of that abuse occurred in church run institutions. I do not single out any church in particular, because nearly all of the church run institutions had one case or more of this kind of abuse.

It cannot go unsaid that the Queensland government and this chamber know that this story is unfinished. The facts of the abuse, and the culture that produced the abuse, were revealed by whistleblowers. I include here someone whom I have spoken about on many occasions, Mr Kevin Lindeberg. For years we have seen the struggle of Mr Lindeberg to reveal the truth about the shredding of the Heiner inquiry documents—documents that we now know revealed the full extent of the information that the Queensland government had on the abuse of children in state institutions. Also worthy of mention are journalists Mr Bruce Grundy of the Weekend Independent and Mr Michael Ware of the Courier-Mail. Both of these people, at some cost to themselves, persisted in revealing the truth and the attempt to cover up the truth.

I want to finish this speech on a positive note. The Beattie government is to be commended for establishing the Forde inquiry. It was an act of courage and decency. Justice, in large measure, has been done for many people who suffered abuse as children when they should have been loved and cared for. If government is about anything, it should be about caring for our children.

But I say to the Queensland government, and even to this chamber: there is still serious unfinished business to attend to concerning the Heiner shredding. The shredding of the Heiner report is part of the reason that this abuse went on for so long without intervention. In that context, the culture of these institutions went unchallenged for all those extra years. The healing then has also taken longer. We owe it to the victims not to regard this report as the end of the matter.

subdebateinfo.title: Batchelor Institute of Indigenous Tertiary Education

talk.start.para: —I rise this evening to inform the Senate and the public of Australia about a historic day tomorrow in the Northern Territory. Unlike last year, I am not going to speak about Territory Day—a day of significance that we celebrate in the Territory with fireworks—but about a day of significance for Aboriginal people in the Territory, and that is the inauguration of the Batchelor Institute of Indigenous Tertiary Education. The Batchelor Institute of Indigenous Tertiary Education Act 1999 was passed by the Northern Territory parliament on 1 June 1999. What does that mean and what significance does that have? Up until today there has been an institution in the Northern Territory called Batchelor College and, with the passing of 1 July tomorrow and this act by the Northern Territory parliament, this institution now becomes an independent institution in its own right.

speech.para: Batchelor College specialises in the provision of higher education and vocational education and training programs for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, mainly from remote and traditionally oriented communities of the Northern Territory, but also from other parts of northern Australia and elsewhere. The college seeks to help Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people achieve their aspirations of community self-determination and self-management by providing recognised and nationally accredited para-professional and professional education and training. All the courses offered are well grounded in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander perspectives. They draw on both their own and Western academic traditions of knowledge and education, which is commonly known in the Northern Territory as education `both ways'. The courses are aimed at enhancing the process of community development.

Central to this challenge is the provision of courses that attempt to engage students in the task of developing appropriate responses to issues of cultural survival, maintenance, renewal and transformation. At the same time, the college's programs seek to facilitate access, equity and social justice within the context of the Australian and international social, political and economic order. The college also affirms, through its work and its courses, the aspirations to self-determination and self-management held by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Close links between the college and the communities it serves have led to the development of a mixed mode form of conducting most courses, combining community based study, which is fairly unique, and research, field study and supervised work experience with short intensive residential workshops at Batchelor College or in other regional locations.

From tomorrow Batchelor College will be owned and governed by its own council, made up mainly of Aboriginal people from communities and organisations around the Northern Territory. This is an important day in the history of education for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people throughout Australia. Batchelor will become the first ever education institution in Australia offering higher education courses to be owned and controlled by indigenous Australians. The changes will allow the college to confer its own accredited awards rather than those being done by the Northern Territory Minister for Education. Even though it aspires to university status, this is a long way down the track. Tomorrow is an important and significant step in achieving that.

Batchelor College is located about 100 kilometres south of Darwin, near the entrance of Litchfield National Park. It began in the mid-1960s as a small annexe of Kormilda College that was then a residential school for Aboriginal students on the outskirts of Darwin, providing short training courses for Aboriginal teacher's aides and assistants in community schools. So it began predominantly as a support mechanism for Aboriginal teacher's assistants within the school system. However, in 1974, the college moved to Batchelor and has occupied its present site in the township of Batchelor since 1982. During 1990 a second campus of the college was established in Alice Springs and later in the same year annexes were opened in Darwin, Nhulunbuy, Katherine and Tennant Creek.

Over the last decade, programs have expanded and diversified in response to the importance Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have placed on gaining accredited awards in the areas of professional and para-professional occupations. From its beginning, the college has grown in size and now caters for about 1,900 students who come from about 250 locations not just in the Territory but across the top of Northern Australia. They study about 30 higher education or vocational education and training courses, with about half of the students enrolled in higher education programs. In addition, between 200 and 300 students undertake short-term vocational programs each year. Batchelor College enrols more Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students at the higher education level than any other tertiary institution in Australia. The majority of the college's students are middle-aged—between 30 and 45 years—and almost 70 per cent of them are women.

In 1989, the Commonwealth government—through the Higher Education Funding Act 1988—recognised Batchelor as a higher education institution, although one outside the unified national system of higher education. In 1995, the college was granted autonomy from the Northern Territory Department of Education as an agency within the public sector. This week it becomes an independent institution.

Batchelor College is governed by a council of 20 members, with a minimum of 17 positions reserved for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people representing communities and various indigenous organisations. The position of chairperson of the college council is reserved for an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander person, and as you may not know but should, it is currently held by ATSIC Chair, Gatjil Djerrkura. The college is organised into three teaching schools—the School of Education Studies, the School of Community Studies and the School of Health Studies—and a Community Education and Training Division. Another section incorporates the college's Centre for Education Research and Development, a curriculum and materials development unit and a special teaching unit with specialist staff in the areas of adult literacy, the teaching of English as a second language, mathematics, art and craft, and computer education.
This morning on radio in the Northern Territory, Gatjil Djerrkura, the chair of the college council said:
It's a new era for indigenous education.
He goes on to say:

There is a feeling of excitement, a feeling of achievement. I think you know that it's a new challenge for indigenous people, particularly in the area of education. We've got a sense of autonomy that is recognised through the act of parliament which gives us that sort of flexibility to advance to be more creative and innovative.

In conclusion, this evening I would specifically and especially like to take this opportunity to extend my best wishes to the retiring director of that college, Mr John Ingram. In my previous role as industrial officer with the education unions in the Territory, I worked with John. I was probably at times one of those people who may have brought a bit of pain into his life as we fought for better conditions for people who worked in the college and undertook the occasional industrial action to improve the workplace. Nevertheless, at the end of the day, Mr Ingram was always somebody who was extremely professional and was at times quite fun to work with. We developed the first award for Batchelor College, which reflects the higher education salary structure and conditions.

What I specifically want to record tonight is the dedication and the hard work that John Ingram has given to that college over his many years of service. He has taken the college from being an annex of the Department of Education through to what he must feel is an exciting day tomorrow, and a day which I think he has long dreamed of. All I can say is that, while unfortunately I cannot be there for the opening ceremony today and the ceremonies that continue over the next three days, I hope that John relishes those celebrations. He has deserved every moment of it. I also commend the work of his staff and the Deputy Director, David McLeay. I want to take this opportunity to congratulate Ms Veronica Arbon on her appointment as the inaugural director. She is an Aboriginal woman who will become the first director of the Batchelor Institute of Indigenous Tertiary Education.

talk.start.para: —In the time remaining, I would like to take the opportunity to briefly once again wish all the retiring senators well and to be the first to welcome the incoming seven, who will be officially in the job from one minute past midnight tonight, including particularly my Democrat colleagues Brian Greig and Aden Ridgeway, who bring the Democrat numbers in this chamber to the highest in the party's history, which is certainly a source of great pride and excitement for the party.

speech.para: I also thank the staff—the clerks, the reporters and others—who worked so hard throughout the session, particularly over the last couple of weeks when we have had longer sitting hours than usual, for all their support and assistance. I hope they enjoy being able to have a slightly less hectic existence during the winter break.

talk.start.para: —We are indeed indebted to the staff of the Senate and of the parliament generally for the service that we have received from them in this recent period and always. I wish them a pleasant break as well. The Senate stands adjourned until Monday, 9 August 1999 at 2 p.m.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry: Value of Advertising
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 206)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 25 November 1998:

question.para: (1) What is the value of advertising placed by: (a) the department; and (b) agencies within the Minister's portfolio, on a month-by-month basis since March 1996.

(3) (a) What proportion of advertising placed by the department or portfolio agencies since March 1996 has been placed through the Office of Government Information and Advertising (OGIA); and (b) what mechanism has been used for that advertising not placed through OGIA.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The value of advertising, excluding staff related gazettal, other recruitment activities and tender notices are:
Two Public Trading Enterprises (PTE), the Australian Dairy Corporation and Wool International had a total of $17,650,330 advertising over this period.
(2) (a) 86.4% department and agencies; 7.4% PTE

subdebateinfo.title: World Health Organisation: Electromagnetic Energy Program
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 615)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 24 March 1999:

question.para: With reference to the World Health Organisation committee dealing with the electromagnetic energy program, a program that has been established to investigate the potential health hazards to the public of radiofrequency radiation and extra low frequency, and the membership of that committee which is comprised of 92 individuals from 17 countries, the United States of America having 20 representatives and Europe having 37 representatives:
(1) In view of the increasing number of mobile phone users in Australia, can reasons be given for the fact that Australia has only two representatives on this committee.
(2) By what criteria does this committee select representatives.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: I presume the honourable Senator is referring to the World Health Organisation International Advisory Committee (IAC) which has been established to oversight the WHO Electromagnetic Fields (EMF) Project.

(1) A report of the 1997 International Advisory Committee meeting lists 4 participants from World Health Organisation (WHO), single representatives from 22 countries including Australia, 6 representatives from collaborating agencies and representatives from 7 international agencies. Australia is an active contributor to the EMF project and receives an invitation to each IAC meeting. Australia can also make written submissions directly or through the International Commission on Non-Ionising Radiation Protection, one of the participating international agencies of which Australia is also a member.

(2) IAC membership comprises representatives of governments who have provided resources to the EMF Project, representatives of collaborating international organisations and representatives of WHO collaborating institutions working on the EMF issue. Currently there are over 40 countries, 7 WHO collaborating centres and 8 international agencies who contribute to the project. Other countries that are interested in the EMF project may send observers to the meeting.

618 Minister for the Environment and Heritage

Can information be provided on the: (a) number; (b) dates; (c) chairmanship; (d) names of Department Foreign Affairs and Trade participants; (e) names of other participants; and (f) purpose of interdepartmental meetings on Kakadu since the Kyoto meeting in December 1998 and to the date of the answer to this question.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The following answer to the honourable senator's questions is provided on behalf of the Minister representing the Prime Minister, the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources and the Minister representing the Attorney-General:

answer.para: (a) Several.
(b) The first meeting was held in December 1998. Meetings are held as necessary. Approximately 7 meetings had been held as of early April.

(c), (d) and (e) I do not believe it is appropriate to identify individual officers. I can assure the Senate that all officers are acting in a professional and ethical manner. I believe they are doing an outstanding job in difficult circumstances.

(f) The purpose of the interdepartmental meetings was to coordinate the Department's activities in facilitating the Australian Government response to the UNESCO Mission report regarding the potential inclusion of Kakadu on the List of World Heritage In Danger.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged Care, upon notice, on 25 March 1999:

question.para: (1) In the 1996-97 Budget what was the projected amount that would be spent on the concessional resident supplement, that is provided to providers in lieu of the accommodation charge.
(2) How much has been spent on the concessional resident supplement for the 1996-97 and 1997-98 financial years, and for the first half of the 1998-99 financial year.

(3) With reference to recent estimates hearings at which the department indicated that the amount spent on the concessional resident supplement was higher than anticipated: what reasons does the department have for the higher than anticipated amount spent on the concessional resident supplement.
(4) What is the average concessional resident ratio in residential aged care facilities, by: (a) state; (b) private/not-for-profit; and (c) metropolitan/rural region.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) A concessional resident is someone who is unable to afford to pay an accommodation bond or charge based on, among other things, the fact they have assets less than two and a half times the single rate of pension. The concessional resident supplement is payable to facilitate their access to residential care. A transitional supplement is payable to all pre 1 October 1997 nursing home residents and those hostel residents who were classified as a FDP (financially disadvantaged person) prior to 1 October 1997. Pre 1 October 1997 residents cannot be assessed for concessional resident status.

The concessional resident arrangements as at the 1996-97 Budget were projected to provide $67 million in a full year if all residents were post 1 October residents. The concessional resident arrangements were revised before the structural reform of aged care was implemented on 1 October 1997. These revised arrangements provided $12 per day per concessional resident for facilities with greater than 40 per cent concessional residents, $7 per day for facilities with 40 per cent or less concessional residents and $3.50 per day for assisted residents. These arrangements were projected to provide $107 million to concessional residents in a full year if all residents were post 1 October residents. The latest projections are that $44 million would be spent in 1997-98, given the new arrangements came into effect 1 October 1997 and $112 million in 1998-99.

(2) There was no expenditure on the concessional resident supplement in 1996-97 as the structural reform of aged care, of which the concessional and transitional resident supplements are components, only came into operation 1 October 1997. $44 million was spent on the concessional and transitional resident supplements in 1997-98 and $61 million has been spent to December in 1998-99. Given that the $61 million is a half-year effect, it is expected that the $112 million projected for 1998-99 will be met.
(3) Expenditure on the concessional resident supplement has been higher than anticipated because there has been a higher number of concessional residents than was first expected.

(4) The concessional resident ratios, based on data as at November 1998, are (a) 47.5 per cent in New South Wales, 41.5 per cent in Victoria, 48.4 per cent in Queensland, 52.9 per cent in Western Australia, 51.0 per cent South Australia, 46.7 per cent in Tasmania, 85.1 per cent in the Northern Territory, 50.2 per cent in the Australian Capital Territory; (b) 50.5 per cent in private facilities, 45.9 per cent in government and adjusted fee facilities, 45.1 per cent in religious and charitable facilities; and (c) 46.4 per cent in metropolitan facilities, 48.3 per cent in rural and remote facilities.

subdebateinfo.title: Cummings, Ms Jane and Strauss, Mr Peter: Provider Applications
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 625)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged Care, upon notice, on 25 March 1999:

question.para: (1) What checks have been carried out under Division 8 of the Aged Care Act 1997 on Ms Jane Cummings and Mr Peter Strauss, who currently reside in Melbourne, in order to satisfy the Secretary of the Department that they were `suitable to provide aged care'.
(2) What were the recommendations to the Secretary concerning any application by Ms Cummings or Mr Strauss for approved provider status under Division 8 of the Act.
(3) (a) Do the provisions of Division 8 apply to the holders of freehold titles of residential aged care facilities; and (b) how are the holders of freehold titles regulated under the Act.

(4) Can the Minister: (a) confirm that Ms Cummings and/or Mr Strauss are connected, either directly or through companies and/or trusts, with the operation of residential aged care facilities in Victoria; and (b) undertake that this issue will be investigated and the Senate informed of any connection found.

(5) Can the Minister: (a) confirm that through various companies and trusts Mr Strauss has an interest in the freehold titles of a number of residential aged care facilities including a nursing home in Berwick; and (b) undertake that this issue will be investigated and the Senate informed of any connection found.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Aged Care has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

answer.para: (1) Mr Peter Strauss is neither an approved provider nor part of the key personnel of an approved provider. Ms Jane Cummings was an approved operator under the National Health Act 1953 and so is taken to be an approved operator under the Aged Care Act 1997 by virtue of the Aged Care (Consequential Provisions) Act 1997.
(2) See answer to (1).
(3) (a) The provisions of Division 8 of the Aged Care Act 1997 apply to "approved providers". If a holder of the freehold title to a facility is also an operator, then the provisions will apply.

(b) Regulation under the Act is based on a person's status as an approved provider. Holders of freehold titles of premises where aged care is delivered, and who are not approved providers, are not regulated under the Act, since they neither receive subsidies nor are responsible under the Act for any aspect of residential care.

(4) (a) Ms Jane Cummings is a key person in terms of the Aged Care Act 1997 of two companies, namely F18 Investments Pty. Ltd. and Stockwell Valley Pty. Ltd. These companies are the Approved Providers under the Aged Care Act 1997 of Mornington Private Nursing Home and Berwick Nursing Home respectively. The approval under the Aged Care Act 1997 is in accordance with Part 2.1 of the Aged Care (Consequential Provisions) Act 1997.

Mr Peter Strauss is not part of the key personnel of any Approved Provider under the Aged Care Act 1997. If Mr Strauss is included in an application for approved provider status as one of the key personnel, any record he may have in the provision of aged care will be taken into account in considering any such application.
(b) See 4 (a) above.
(5) (a) The Department does not collect information on the holders of the freehold title of residential aged care facilities except where they are also approved providers.
(b) There is no power under the Aged Care Act 1997 to investigate the business circumstances of persons who neither receive subsidies nor are held responsible for care of residents.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 28 April 1999:

question.para: With reference to the answer to question on notice No. 515:

(1) Who were the `third parties' that contributed information to each of the following regional forest agreement (RFA) data sets: (a) forest vegetation communities; (b) rare or threatened forest communities; (c) forest vegetation classes; (d) high quality old-growth forest of national estate significance; (e) rare, endangered or uncommon old-growth forests of national estate significance; (f) old-growth forests; (g) species site locations for the comprehensive regional assessment; (h) timber harvesting history; (i) forest users' survey; and (j) business dependency survey.

(2) For each of the data sets in (1): (a) what is an estimate of the proportion of the total data set that was provided by third parties; (b) what conditions did each of the third party information contributors place on the use of their data during RFA development and availability of their data after the RFA was signed; and (c) which data owners required the data to be classified as `restricted'.
(3) If one data owner specifies that access to his, her or its data should be restricted, is the whole data set then classified as restricted; if so, why.
(4) Can electronic copies be provided of the data sets listed in (1).

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) I am advised that third parties who contributed to the listed data sets included individuals, private businesses and companies. For some of these data sets there were large numbers of contributors. The identity of the individual contributors is restricted in deference to assurances regarding individual privacy and the protection of commercial confidentiality and, in some cases, to protect the values represented in the data sets. The identity of third party data owners and data providers is held by the particular Data Custodians listed in the RFA, should it be necessary to contact them in relation to a formal application to the relevant Data Custodians for access to the data sets.

(2) (a) and (b) I am advised that it is difficult to provide clear estimates of the proportions of the jointly owned data sets provided by third parties as this information was not required when specifications for the data sets were drawn up. The data sets listed at (1) (a) to (f) include a substantial propor tion of private forest data. The information about private forests was derived from the 1995 Private Forest Resources Inventory, for which information was supplied by private landowners and industrial companies on condition that it would only be made available on a restricted basis. The data supplied by third parties for the data sets listed at (1) (g)—threatened species locations—is also substantial. As was noted in the answer to question on notice no. 515, this information is restricted in order to protect the values to which it relates. In relation to the data set at (1) (h), at the time of the Regional Forest Agreement, roughly 30 per cent of Tasmanian Forests were privately owned. As a result, it is estimated that a similar proportion of the data (ie 30 per cent) came from private sources and would therefore be restricted on the basis of commercial confidentiality. Please note that this is an estimate only and relates only to this category. Data sets at (1) (i) and (j) contain almost 100 per cent unit record information collected from surveys of individuals and businesses, which are subject to confidentiality provisions. As part of the surveys, all respondents were assured that no identifiable unit record information would be released and that the only publicly available data would be in aggregate format and would only be used for the purposes of the Comprehensive Regional Assessment/RFA social assessment process.

(c) I am advised that much of the data relating to private forests was obtained on the basis of assurances that individual personal or business details would not be publicly released. Some data providers were also concerned about the need to protect the particular values represented in the data set, for example threatened species locations.

(3) Yes. The protection of the "restricted" category can only be provided to data classified as such if the entire data set is classified at that level. I am advised that the integrity of the RFA processes and of future related projects relies upon achieving cooperation with a range of data owners or data providers for supply of their data. This cooperation is underpinned by the commitment of governments to honour the conditions placed on use of the data by data owners or providers.

(4) I am advised that electronic copies of the data sets listed at (1) cannot be provided in response to this question. As advised in the answer to question on notice no. 515, Clause 90 and Attachment 14 of the Tasmanian RFA set out the conditions governing access and use of restricted and other data sets. Some of the data sets are in electronic form, as indicated under Data Type in Attachment 14 of the RFA. Formal application to the Data Custodians (listed in Attachment 14 of the Tasmanian RFA) for access to the electronic data sets would be considered on its merits, with due regard given to such matters as the intended use of the data and any relevant technical considerations.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs: Grants to the Electorate of Bass
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1112)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 9 June 1999:

question.para: (1) What programs and/or grants administered by the Minister's department provide assistance to people living in the federal electorate of Bass.
(2) What was the level of funding provided through these programs and grants for the 1997-98 and 1998-99 financial years.
(3) What level of funding provided through these programs and grants has been appropriated for the 1999-2000 financial years.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) People living in the electorate of Bass may benefit from a wide range of departmental programs and services. The following is a summary of the more specifically identifiable programs and grants which assist people living in that electorate:

(a) My Department provides assistance to people living in the federal electorate of Bass under the Grants for Migrant Community Services, which includes the Community Settlement Services (CSS) Scheme and Migrant Resource Centres /Migrant Service Agencies (MRCs/MSAs).

The CSS Scheme provides a subsidy to non-profit community and service organisations to deliver settlement assistance targeted to the needs of refugees, humanitarian entrants and migrants who have demonstrated settlement needs.
MRCs/MSAs assist in meeting the settlement needs of overseas-born residents, particularly those who have arrived in Australia recently.
CSS Scheme
The following organisations, which are located in the federal electorate of Bass, have received funds under the CSS Scheme in 1997/98 and 1998/99.
Launceston Chinese
Migrant Resource Centre (MRC) of Northern Tasmania.
Women Born Overseas Wynyard (Auspiced by the MRC of Northern Tasmania)
Australian Croatian Social and Sporting Club
MRC of Northern Tasmania
MRCs/MSAs
In the federal electorate of Bass there is one MRC, the MRC of Northern Tasmania. It has been funded in 1997/98 and 1998/99.

(b) My Department also funds the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy (IHSS), which provides a national framework for improving humanitarian settlement services for Humanitarian Program entrants most in need.

Under the IHSS worker grants, the MRC of Northern Tasmania was funded in 1997/98 and in 1998/99 to provide case management by two part-time workers based in Burnie and Devonport for migrants and humanitarian entrants and to provide ongoing case management for migrants and humanitarian entrants in the Northern Region of Tasmania.

In 1998/99 the MRC of Northern Tasmania received a project grant under the IHSS to develop a model and provide a torture and trauma counselling worker in the north of the state in conjunction with the Department of Health and Family Services.

(c) In August 1998 I launched the Living in Harmony (LiH) Initiative which includes a Community Grants program. The Initiative provides funding for community education projects that promote harmony and reduce racism. The following organisation, which is located in the federal electorate of Bass, has been funded under the LiH Initiative in 1998/99:

Migrant Resource Centre (MRC) of Northern Tasmania to address intolerance and disharmony via a free-to-air satirical Community Services Announcement for the wider community shown on commercial TV, a video (including work kit) for schools and community groups and an Internet site.

Funding was also provided to the Council for International Student Support (Tasmania), based in Hobart, to implement a number of initiatives in Launceston and Hobart. These will address issues of racial and social tension currently being experienced in these communities.

(d) The Adult Migrant English Program (AMEP) provides up to 510 hours of English language tuition to newly arrived migrants and refugees who do not have functional English. Under additional funding which commenced in 1997-98, refugees who are assessed as needing special assistance because of experience of torture and trauma are provided with up to 100 hours of additional English tuition under an AMEP preparatory program. AMEP funding in Tasmania is determined by the number of eligible migrants and refugees who enrol with the AMEP service provider, TAFE Tasmania. It is estimated that approximately 247 clients, 33 of whom were from the Bass electorate, accessed the program in 1998/99.

(2) (a) Total CSS Scheme funding in 1997/98 was $4,360, comprising: Launceston Chinese Association—$1,500; Migrant Resource Centre (MRC) of Northern Tasmania—$2,136; Women Born Overseas Wynyard (Auspiced by the MRC of Northern Tasmania)—$724.
Total CSS Scheme funding in 1998/99 was $1,000, comprising: Australian Croatian Social and Sporting Club—$500; MRC of Northern Tasmania—$500.
MRCs/MSAs: MRC of Northern Tasmania received $193,592 in 1997/98 and $198,346 in 1998/99.
(b) IHSS: MRC of Northern Tasmania: $70,660 in 1997/98 and $84,290 in 1998/99.

(c) LiH funding to the MRC of Northern Tasmania was $30,000 in 1998/99. Funding provided in 1998/99 to the Council for International Student Support (Tasmania), to implement initiatives in Launceston and Hobart, was $34,850.
(d) AMEP funding to Tasmania in 1997/98 totalled $520,000.
AMEP funding to Tasmania in 1998/99 totalled around $569,000.
(3) (a) Subject to the MRC of Northern Tasmania meeting the conditions contained in the Service Agreement, $201,975 has been allocated as MRC/MSA core funding.
A decision regarding the distribution of CSS Scheme funding will not be made until late July/early August 1999.
(b) A decision regarding the distribution of IHSS funding will also be made in late July/early August.

(c) Subject to the MRC of Northern Tasmania meeting their agreed Milestones their LiH funding in 1999/2000 will be $24,000. Subject to the Council for International Student Support (Tasmania) meeting their agreed Milestones, for initiatives in Launceston and Hobart, their LiH funding in 1999/2000 will be $27,880.
(d) AMEP funding to Tasmania in 1999/2000 is estimated to be around $523,000, based on projected client numbers.
